sp.l: Though no man less can fear the Greeks then I,
Yet there's no Virgin of more tender heart
More ready to cry out, who knows the consequence,
Then Hector is; for modest doubt is mix'd
With manly courage best, let Hellen go.
If we have lost so many lives of ours,
To keep a thing not ours; not worth to us
The vallue of a man, what reason is there
Still to retain the cause of so much ill?

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Fy, fy, my noble Brother!
Weigh you the worth and honour of a King,
So great as Asia's Monarch in a scale
Of common ounces thus?
Are fears and reasons fit to be consider'd,
When a Kings fame is question'd?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Brother, she's not worth
What her defence has cost us.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: What's ought but as 'tis vallued?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: But vallue dwels not in opinion only:
It holds the dignity and estimation,
As well, wherein 'tis precious of it self.
As in the prizer, 'tis Idolatry
To make the Service greater than the God.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: We turn not back the Silks upon the Merchant
When we have worn 'em: the remaining food
Throw not away because we now are full.
If you confess 'twas wisedome Paris went,
As you must needs; for you all cry'd go, go,
If you'll confess he brought home noble prize
As you must needs, for you all clapt your hands,
And cry'd inestimable: why do you now
So underrate the vallue of your purchase?
For let me tell you 'tis unmanly theft
When we have taken what we fear to keep!

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: There's not the meanest Spirit in our party
Without a heart to dare, or Sword to draw,
When Hellen is defended: none so noble
Whose life were ill bestowed, or death unfam'd,
When Helleu is the Subject.

sp.speaker: Priam.
sp.l: So says Paris.
Like one besotted on effeminate joys,
He has the honey still, but these the gall.

sp.speaker: Aeneas.
sp.l: He not proposes meerly to himself
The pleasures such a beauty brings with it:
But he wou'd have the stain of Hellen's rape
Wip'd off in honourable keeping her.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Troilus and Aeneas you have sayd:
If saying superficiall things be reason.
But if this Hellen be anothers wife,
The Morall laws of Nature and of Nation's
Speak loud she be restor'd: thus to persist
In doing wrong, extenuates not wrong,
But makes it much more so: Hectors opinion
Is this, is in way of truth: yet ne'retheless
My sprightly Brother I encline to you
In resolution to defend her still:
For 'tis cause on which our Trojan honour
And common reputation will depend.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Why there you touch'd the life of our designe:
Were it not glory that we covet more
Then war and vengeance (beasts and womens pleasure)
I woud not wish a drop of Trojan blood
Spent more in her defence: But oh my Brother
She is a subject of renoun and honour,
And I presume brave Hector wou'd not lose
The rich advantage of his future fame
For the wide worlds revenew:— I have business;
But glad I am to leave you thus resolv'd.
When such arms strike, ne're doubt of the success.

sp.speaker: Aeneas.
sp.l: May we not guesse?

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: You may, and be deceiv'd.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: A woman on my life: ev'n so it happens,
Religion, state affairs, whater'es the theme
It ends in women still.

sp.speaker: Priam.
sp.l: See here's your wife
To make that maxim good.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Welcome Andromache: your looks are cheerfull;
You bring some pleasing news.

sp.speaker: Andro.
sp.l: Nothing that's serious.
Your little Son Astyanax has employ'd me
As his Ambassadresse.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Upon what errand?

sp.speaker: Andro.
sp.l: No less then that his Grandfather this day
Would make him, Knight: he longs to kill a Grecian:
For shou'd he stay to be a man, he thinks
Youll kill 'em all; and leave no work for him.

sp.speaker: Priam.
sp.l: Your own blood, Hector.

sp.speaker: Andro.
sp.l: And therefore he designes to send a challenge
To Agamemnon, Ajax, or Achilles
To prove they do not well to burn our fields;
And keep us coop'd like prisner's in a Town:
To lead this lazy life.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: What sparks of honour
Fly from this child! the God's speak in him sure:
— It shall be so— I'le do't.

sp.speaker: Priam.
sp.l: What means my Son?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: To send a challenge to the boldest Greek;
Is not that Country ours? those fruitfull Fields
Wash'd by yon Silver flood, are they not ours?
Those teeming Vines that tempt our longing eyes,
Shall we behold e'm? shall we call e'm ours
And date not make e'm so? by Heavens I'le know
Which of these haughty Grecians, dares to think
He can keep Hector prisner here in Troy.

sp.speaker: Priam.
sp.l: If Hector only were a private Man,
This wou'd be courage, but in him 'tis madness.
The generall safety on your life depends;
And shou'd you perish in this rash attempt

sp.speaker: Troy
sp.l: with a groan, would feel her Soul go out:
And breath her last in you.

sp.speaker: Aeneas.
sp.l: The task you undertake is hazardous:
Suppose you win, what wou'd the profit be?
If Ajax or Achilles fell beneath
Your thundring Arm, wou'd all the rest depart?
Wou'd Agamemnon, or his injur'd Brother
Set sayl for this? then it were worth your danger:
But, as it is, we throw our utmost stake
Against whole heaps of theirs.

sp.speaker: Priam.
sp.l: He tells you true.

sp.speaker: Aeneas.
sp.l: Suppose one, Ajax, or Achilles lost.
They can repair with more that single lose:

sp.speaker: Troy
sp.l: has but one, one Hector.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: No Aeneas?
What then art thou; and what is Troilus?
What will Astyanax be?

sp.speaker: Priam.
sp.l: An Hector one day.
But you must let him live to be a Hector.
And who shall make him such when you are gone?
Who shall instruct his tenderness in arms,
Or give his childhood lessons of the war?
Who shall defend the promise of his youth
And make it bear in Manhood? the young Sappling
Is shrowded long beneath the Mother tree
Before it be transplanted from its Earth,
And trust it self for growth.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Alas, my Father!
You have not drawn one reason from yourself,
But publick safety, and my Sons green years:
In this neglecting that main argument
Trust me you chide my filiall piety:
As if I cou'd be won from my resolves
By Troy, or by my Son, or any name
More dear to me than yours.

sp.speaker: Priam.
sp.l: I did not name my self; because I know
When thou art gone, I need no Grecian Sword,
To help me dye, but only Hectors loss.
Daughter, why speak not you? why stand you silent?
Have you no right in Hector, as a wife?

sp.speaker: Andro.
sp.l: I would be worthy to be Hectors wife:
And had I been a Man, as my Soul's one
I had aspir'd a nobler name, his friend.
How I love Hector, (need I say I love him?)
I am not but in him:
But when I see him arming for his Honour,
His Country and his Gods, that martial fire
That mounts his courage, kindles ev'n to me:
And when the Trojan Matrons wait him out
With pray'rs, and meet with blessings his return;
The pride of Virtue, beats within my breast,
To wipe away the sweat and dust of War:
And dress my Heroe, glorious in his wounds.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Come to my Arms, thou manlier Virtue come;
Thou better Name than wife! wou'dst thou not blush
To hug a coward thus?

sp.speaker: Priam.
sp.l: Yet still I fear!

sp.speaker: Andro.
sp.l: There spoke a woman, pardon Royal Sir;
Has he not met a thousand lifted Swords,
Of thick rank'd Grecians, and shall one affright him?
There's not a day but he encounters Armles;
And yet as safe, as if the broad brim'd Shield
That Pallas wears, were held 'twixt him and death.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Thou knowst me well; and thou shalt praise me more,
Gods make me worthy of thee!

sp.speaker: Andro.
sp.l: You shall be
My Knight this day, you fhall not wear a cause
So black as Hellens rape upon your breast,
Let Paris fight for Hellen; guilt for guilt,
But when you fight for Honour and for me,
Then let our equal Gods behold an Act,
They may not blush to Crown.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Aeneas go.
And bear my Challenge to the Grecian Camp,
If there be one amongst the best of Greece,
Who holds his honour higher then his ease,
Who knows his valour, and knows not his fear;
Who loves his Mistress more then in confession:
And dares avow her beauty and her worth,
In other Arms then hers; to him this Challenge.
I have a Lady of more truth and beauty,
Then ever Greek did compass in his arms:
And will to morrow, with the Trumpets call,
Mid-way, between their Tents, and these our Walls,
Maintains what I have said, if any come
My Sword shall honour him, if none shall dare,
Then shall I say at my return to Troy,
The Grecian dames, are Sun-burnt, and not worth
The splinter of a Lance.

sp.speaker: Aeneas.
sp.l: It shall be told 'em,
As boldly as you gave it.

sp.speaker: Priam.
sp.l: Heav'n protect thee.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: YOnder he stands poor wretch! there stands he, with such a look, and such a face, and such begging eyes; there he stands poor prisoner.

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.p: What a deluge of words do you pour out Uncle, to say just nothing?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Nothing do you call it, is that nothing, do you call it nothing? why he looks for all the World, like one of your rescally Malefactors, just thrown off the Gibbet, with his cap down, his arms ty'd down, his feet sprunting, his body swinging, nothing do you call it? this is nothing with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.p: Or, what think you of a hurt bird, that flutters about with a broken wing?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Why go to then, he cannot fly away then, then, that's certain, that's undoubted: there he lies to be taken up: but if you had seen him, when I said to him, take a good heart man, and follow me: and fear no colours, and speak, your mind man: she can never stand you: she will fall, and 'twere a leaf in Autumn.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: Did you tell him all this without my consent?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Why you did consent, your eyes consented; they blab'd, they leer'd, their very corners blabb'd. But you'll say your tongue sayd nothing. No I warrant it: your tongue was wiser; your tongue was better bred: your tongue kept its own counsell: Nay, I'le say that for you, your tongue sayd nothing. Well such a shamefac'd couple did I never see days o' my life: so fraid of one another; such ado to bring you to the business: well if this job were well over, if ever I lose my pains again wtth an awkard couple, let me be painted in the signe-post for the Labour in vain: fye upon't, fye upon't; there's no conscience in't: all honest people will cry shame on't.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: Where is this Monster to be shown? what's to be given for a Sight of him?

sp.speaker: Pand
sp.p: Why ready money, ready money; you carry it about you: give and take is square-dealing; for in my conscience he's as errant a maid as you are: I was fain to use violence to him, to pull him hither: and he pull'd and I pull'd: for you must know he's absolutely the strongest youth in Troy: to'ther day he took Hellen is one hand, and Paris in to'ther, and danc'd 'em at one another at arms-end, and 'twere two Moppets: there was a back, there were bone and Sinnews: there was a back for you.

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.p: For these good procuring Offices you'l be damn'd one day Uncle.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Who I damn'd? faith I doubt I shall: by my troth I think I shall, nay if a man be damn'd for doing good, as thou saist, it may go hard with me.

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.p: Then I'le not see Prince Troilus? I 'le not be accessary to your damnation.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p:
How, not see Prince Troilus? why I have engag'd, I have promis'd, I have past my word, I care not for damning, let me alone for damning; I vallue not damning in comparison with my word. If I am damn'd it shall be a good damning to thee girl, thou shalt be my
heir, come 'tis a virtuous girl, thou shalt help me to keep my word, thou shalt see Prince Troilus.

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.p: The ventures great.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: No venture in the World, thy Mother ventur'd it for thee, and thou shalt venture it for my little Cousin that must be.

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.p: Weigh but my fears, Prince Troilus is young.—

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Marry is he, there's no fear in that I hope, the fear were if he were old and feeble.

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.p: And I a woman.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: No fear yet, thouart a Woman, and he's a Man, put them two together, put 'em together.

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.p: And if I shou'd be frail.—

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: There's all my fear that thou art not frail: thou shou'dst be frail, all flesh is frail.

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.p: Are you my Uncle, and can give this counsel to your own Brothers daughter.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: If thou wert my own daughter a thousand times over, I cou'd do no better for thee; what wou'dst thou have girl, he's a Prince and a young Prince, and a loving young Prince! an Uncle dost thou call me, by Cupid I am a father to thee; get thee in, get thee in girl, I hear him coming. And do you hear Neice! I give you leave, [Eeit Cressida. to deny a little 'twill be decent: but take heed of obstinacy, that's a vice; no obstinacy my dear Niece.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.p: Now Pandarus.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Now, my sweet Prince! have you seen my Niece? no I know you have not.

sp.speaker: Troylus:
sp.l: No Pandarus; I stalk about your doors
Like a strange Soul upon the stygian banks
Staying for waftage: O be thou my Charon,
And give me a swift transportanee to Elysium,
And fly with me to Cressida.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Walk here a moment more: I'le bring her straight.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.p: I fear she will not come: most sure she will not.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: How not come, and I her Uncle! why I tell you Prince, she twitters at you. Ah poor sweet Rogue, ah little Rogue, now does she think, and think, and think again of what must be betwixt you two. Oh sweet,— oh sweet— O— what not come, and I her Uncle?

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.p: Still thou flatter'st me; but prithee flatter still; for I wou'd hope; I wou'd not wake out of my pleasing dream: oh hope how sweet thou art! but to hope always, and have no effect of what we hope!

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p:
Oh faint heart, faint heart! well there's much good matter in these old proverbs! No, she'll not come I warrant her; she has no
blood of mine in her, not so much as will fill a flea: but if she does not come, and come, and come with a swing into your arms, I say no more, but she has renounc'd all grace, and there's an end.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.p: I will believe thee: go then, but be sure:

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: No, you wou'd not have me go; you are indifferent: shall I go say you: speak the word then:— yet I care not: you may stand in your own light; and lose a sweet young Ladies heart: well, I shall not go then!

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.p: Fly, fly, thou tortur'st me.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Do I so, do I so! do I torture you indeed! well I will go.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.p: But yet thou dost not go?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: I go immediately, directly, in a twinkling, with a thought. yet you think a man never does enough for you: I have been labouring in your business like any Moyle. I was with Prince Paris this morning, to make your excuse at night for not supping at Court: and I found him, faith how do you think I found him; it does my heart good to think how I found him: yet you think a man never does enough for you.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.p: Will you go then, what's this to Cressida?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Why you will not hear a Man; what's this to Cressida? why I found him abed, abed with Hellena by my troth: 'tis a sweet Queen, a sweet Queen, a very sweet Queen;— but she's nothing to my Cousin Cressida; she's a blowse, a gipsie, a Tawney-moor to my Cousin Cressida: And she lay with one white arm underneath the whorsons neck: oh such a white, lilly white, round, plump arm it was— and you must know it was stript up to th'elbows: and she did so kisse him, and so huggle him:— as who shou'd say—

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.p: But still thou stay'st: what's this to Cressida?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Why I made your excuse to your Brother Paris; that I think's to Cressida; but such an arm, such a hand, such taper fingers, tother hand was under the bed-cloaths, that I saw not, I confess, that hand I saw not.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.p: Again thou tortur'st me.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Nay I was tortur'd too; old as I am, I was tortur'd too: but for all that, I cou'd make a shift, to make him, to make your excuse, to make your father;— by Jove when I think of that hand, I am so ravish'd, that I know not what I say: I was tortur'd too.
Well I go, I go; I fetch her, I bring her, I conduct her: not come quoth a, and I her Uncle!

sp.speaker: Troilus.
sp.l: Im'e giddy; expectation whirls me round:
The imaginary relish is so sweet,
That it enchants my sence; what will it be
When I shall taste that Nectar?
It must be either death, or joy too fine
For the capacity of human powers.
I fear it much: and I do fear beside,
That I shall lose distinction in my joys:
As does a battle, when they charge on heaps
A flying Enemy.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: She's making her ready: she'll come straight, you must be witty now; she does so blush, and fetches her breath so short, as if she were frighted with a spright: 'tis the prettiest villain, she fetches her breath so short, as 'twere a new ta'ne Sparrow.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Just such a passion, does heave up my breast!
My heart beats thicker than a feavourish pulse:
I know not where I am, nor what I do:
Just like a slave, at unawares encountring
The eye of Majesty:— Leade on, I'le follow.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: I have conceiv'd an embryo in my brain:
Be you my time to bring it to some shape.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: What is't, Vlysses?

sp.speaker: Ulyss.
sp.l: The seeded pride,
That has to this maturity blown up
In rank Achilles, must or now be cropt,
Or shedding, breed a nursery of like ill,
To overtop us all.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: That's my opinion.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: This challenge which AEneas as brings from Hector,
However it be spred in general terms,
Relates in purpose only to Achilles.
And will it wake him to the answer think you?

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: It ought to do: whom can we else oppose
Who cou'd from Hector bring his honour off,
If not Achilles the Successe of this
Although particular, will give an Omen
Of good or bad, ev'n to the general cause.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: Pardon me Nestor, if I contradict you.
Therefore 'tis fit Achilles meet not Hector.
Let us like Merchants show our coursest wares,
And think perchance they'll sell: but if they do not
The lustre of our better yet unshown
Will show the better; let us not consent
Our greatest warriour shou'd be match'd with Hector.
For both our honour and our shame in this,
Shall be attended with strange followers.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: I see e'm not with my old eyes; what are they?

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: What glory our Achilles gains from Hector.
Were he not proud we all should share with him:
But he already is too insolent:
And we had better parch in Affrick Sun
Than in his pride, shou'd he scape Hector fair.
But grant he shou'd be foyl'd
Why then our common reputation suffers,
In that of our best Man: No, make a Lottery;
And by device let blockish Ajax draw
The chance to fight with Hector: among our selves
Give him allowance as the braver Man;
For that will physick the great Myrmidon,
Who swells with loud applause; and make him fall
His Crest, if brainless Ajax come safe off.
If not, we yet preserve a fair opinion,
That we have better men.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Now I begin to relish thy advice:
Come let us go to Agamemnon straight,
T'inform him of our project.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: 'Tis not ripe.
The skilfull Surgeon will not lanch a sore
Till Nature has digested and prepar'd
The growing humours to his healing purpose.
Else must he often grieve the patients sence,
When one incision once well-time'd woul'd serve:
Are not Achilles, and dull Ajax friends?

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: As much as fools can be.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: That knot of friendsip first must be unty'd
Ere we can reach our ends; for while they love each other
Both hating us, will draw too strong a byasse,
And all the Camp will lean that way they draw:
For brutall courage is the Soldiers Idoll:
So, if one prove contemptuous, back'd by to'ther,
'Twill give the law to cool and sober sence,
And place the power of war in Mad-mens hands.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Now I conceive you; were they once divided,
And one of them made ours, that one would check
The others towring growth: and keep both low,
As Instruments, and not as Lords of war.
And this must be by secret coals of envy,
Blown in their brest: comparisons of worth;
Great actions weigh'd of each: and each the best,
As we shall give him voice.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: Here comes Thersites.
Who feeds on Ajax: yet loves him not, because he cannot love.
But as a Species, differing from mankinde,
Hatss all he sees; and rails at all he knows;
But hates them most, from whom he most receives.
Disdaining that his lot shou'd be so low.
That he shou'd want the kindeness which he takes.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: There's none so fit an Engine: Save ye Thersites.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: Hayl noble Grecian, Thou relief of toyls,
Soul of our mirth, and joy of sullen war.
In whose converse our winter-nights are short,
And Summer-days not tedious.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.l: Hang you both.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: How hang us both!

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.l: But hang thee first, thou very reverend fool!
Thou sapless Oke, that liv'st by wanting thought.
And now in thy three hundreth year repin'st
Thou should'st be fell'd: hanging's a civil death,
The death of men: thou canst not hang: thy trunk
Is only fit for gallows to hang others.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: A fine greeting.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.l: A fine old Dotard, to repine at hanging
At such an Age! what saw the Gods in thee
That a Cock-Sparrow shou'd but live three years,
And thou shoud'st last three Ages! he's thy better;
He uses life: he treads himself to death.
Thou hast forgot thy use some hundred years:
Thou stump of Man, thou worn-out broom: thou lumber.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: I'le hear no more of him, his poyson works;
What curse me for my age!

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: Hold, you mistake him, Nestor; 'tis his custome:
What malice is there in a mirthfull scene!
'Tis but a keen-edg'd Sword, spread o're with blame
To heal the wound it makes:

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.l: Thou beg'st a curse!
May'st thou quit scores then, and be hang'd on Nestor,
Who hangs on thee: thou lead'st him by the nose:
Thou paly'st him like a puppet; speak'st within him,
And when thou hast contirv'd some dark design
To loose a thousand Greeks; make dogs meat of us,
Thou layst thy Cuckows egg within his nest,
And mak'st him hatch it: teachest his remembrance
To lye; and say, the like of it was practis'd
Two hundred years ago; thou bring'st the brain;
And he brings only beard to vouch thy plots;

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: I'me no mans fool.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.l: Then be thy own, that's worse.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: He'll rail all day.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: Then we shall learn all day.
Who forms the body to a gracefull carriage
Must imitate our awkard motions first;
The same prescription does the wise Thersites
Apply to mend our minds. The same he uses
To Ajax, to Achilles; to the rest;
His Satyrs are the phyfick of the Camp.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.l: Wou'd they were poyson to't, Rats-bane and Hemlock:
Nothing else can mend you; and those two brawny fools.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: He hits e'm right:
Are they not such my Nestor?

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.l: Dolt-heads, Asses.
And beasts of burthen; Ajax and Achilles!
The pillars, no, the porters of the war.
Hard-headed Rogues! Engines, meer wooden Engines,
Push'd on to do your work.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: They are indeed.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.l: But what a Rogue art thou
To say they are indeed: Heaven made e, m horses
And thou put'st on their harnesse: rid'st and spur'st e'm:
Usurp'st upon heav'ns fools, and mak'st e'm thine.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: No: they are headstrong fools to be corrected
By none but by Thersites: thou alone
Canst tame, and train e'm to their proper use;
And doing this mayst claim a just reward
From Greece, and Royall Agamemnons, hands.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.l: Ay, when you need a man, you talk of giving;
For wit's a dear commodity among you:
But when you do not want him, then stale porridge,
A starv'd dog wou'd not lap; and furrow water
Is all the wine we taste, give drabs and pimps:
He have no gifts with hooks at end of e'm.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: Is this a Man, O Nestor to be bought!
Asia's not price enough! bid the world for him.
And shall this man, this Hermes, this Apollo,
Sit lagg of Ajax table? almost minstrell,
And with his presence grace a brainless feast?
Why they con sence from him grow wits by rote,
And yet, by ill repeating, libell him;
Making his wit their nonsence: nay they scorn him;
Call him bought rayler, mercenary tongue!
Play him for sport at meals, and kick him off.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.l: Yes they can kick; my buttocks feel they can:
They have their Asses tricks: but I'Ie eat pebbles,
Ile starve; 'tis brave to starve, 'tis like a Soldier;
Before I'Ie feed those wit-starv'd rogues with sence.
They shall eat dry, and choke for want of wit,
Ere they be moisten'd with one drop of mine.
Ajax, and Achilles, two mudd-walls of fool,
That only differ in degrees of thicknesse.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: I'de be reveng'd of both, when wine fumes high,
Set e'm to prate, to boast their brutall strength,
To vye their stupid courage, till they quarrell
And play at hard-head with their empty Skulls.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.l: Yes; they shall but and kick; and all the while
Ile think they kick for me: they shall fell timber
On both sides; and then log-wood will be cheap.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: And Agamemnon—

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.l: Pox of Agamemnon;
Cannot I do a mischief for my self
But he must thank me for't!
Away; our work is done.

sp.speaker: Thers
sp.l: This Agamemnon is a King of clouts:
A chip in porredge.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: Thersites!

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.l: Set up to frighten Daws from Cherry trees.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: Dogg!

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.l: A standard to march under!

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: Thou bitch-woolf! canst thou not hear! feel then.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.l: The plague of Greece, and Hellens Pox light on thee,
Thou mungrill mastiffe; thou beef-witted Lord.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: Speak then, thou mouldy leaven of the Camp.
Speak or Ile beat thee into handsomeness.

sp.speaker: Thers
sp.l: I shall sooner rayle thee into wit: thou canst kick, can't thou?
A red murrayn on thy Jades tricks!

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: Tell me the Proclamation:

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.l: Thou art proclaim'd a fool I think.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: You whorson Cur take that.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.l: Thou Scurvy valiant Asse.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: Thou slave.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: Thou Lord!— I, do, do,— wou'd my buttocks were Iron for thy sake.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: Why how now Ajax! wherefore do you this?
How now Thersites, what's the matter man!

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: I say this Ajax wears his wit in's belly, and his guts in brains.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.p: Peace fool.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: I wou'd have peace; but the fool will not.

sp.speaker: Patrocl
sp.p: But what's the quarrell!

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: I bad him tell me the proclamation, and he rails upon me.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: I serve thee not:

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: I shall cut out your tongue!

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter; I shall speak as much sence as thou afterwards: Ile see you hang'd ere I come any more to your Tent: Ile keep where theres wit stirring, and leave the faction of fools.—

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.p: Nay, thou shalt not go Thersites, till we have squees'd the venome out of thee: prithee inform us of this Proclamation.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: Why you empty fuz-balls, your heads are full of nothing else but Proclamations.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: Tell us the news I say.

sp.speaker: Thirs.
sp.p: You say! why you never said any thing in all your life! But since you will know, 'tis proclam'd through the Army, that Hector is to cudgell you to morrow.

sp.speaker: Achilles.
sp.p: How cudgell him, Thersites!

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: Nay, you may take a childs part ont if you have so much courage, for Hector has challeng'd the toughest of the Greeks: and 't is in dispute which of your two heads is the sonndest timber.
sp.l: A knotty piece of work he 'll have betwixt your noddles,

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: If Hector be to fight with any Greeke,
He knows his Man.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: Yes; he may know his man, without Art Magick.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: So he had need: for to my certain knowledge neither of you two are conjurers to inform him.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.p: to Ajax. You do not mean your self, sure.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: I mean nothing

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: Thou mean'st so always.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.p: Umh! mean nothing!

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: aside. Jove if it be thy will, let these two fools quarrell about nothing: 'tis a cause that's worthy of'em.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: You sayd he knew his Man: is there but one?
One Man amongst the Greeks!

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: Since you will have it,
but one to fight with Hector.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: Then I am he;

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.p: Weak Ajax.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: Weak Achilles.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: Weak indeed: God help you both!

sp.speaker: Patroc.
sp.p: Come, this must be no quarrell.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: There's no cause for't.

sp.speaker: Patroc.
sp.p: He tells you true; you are both equall

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: Fools.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.p: I can brook no comparisons.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.p: Well Ajax.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: Well Achilles.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: So now they quarrell in Monosyllables: A word and a blow, and't be thy will.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.p: You may hear more.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: I wou'd.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.p: Expect,

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: Curse on them, they want wine: your true fool will never fight without it. Or a drab a drab: Oh for a commodious Drabb 'em! wou'd Hellen had been here! then it had come to something.
sp.l: Dogs, Lyons, Bulls, for Females tear and gore:
And the Beast Man, is valiant for his whore.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: SHall the Idiot Ajax use me thus! he beats me and I rail at him: O worthy satisfaction! wou'd I cou'd beat him, and he rail'd at me! Then there's Achilles, a rare Engineer: if Troy be not taken till these two undermine it, the walls will stand till they fall of themselves: Now the Plague on the whole Camp, or rather the Pox: for that's a curse dependent on those that sight as we do for a Cuckolds queen.— What ho, my Lord Achilles.

sp.speaker: Patroc.
sp.p: Who's there, Thersites! Good Thersites come in and rail.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: aside. If I cou'd have remembred an Asse with gilt trappings, thou hadst not slip'd out of my contemplation. But 'tis no matter; thy self upon thy self: the common curse of mankind, folly and ignorance be thine in great abundance: Heavens belsse thee from a Tutor; and discipline come not near thee.
sp.l: I have said my prayers; and the devil Envy say Amen.
Where's Achilles!
sp.p: Who's there Thersites! why my digestion, why hast thou not serv'd thy self to my table, so many meals! come begin what's Agamemnon?

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: Thy Commander, Achilles: then tell me Pauroclus, what's Achilles?

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.p: Thy Benefactor Thersites; then tell me prithee what's thy self?

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: Thy knower, Patrcolus; then tell me, Patroclus, what art thou?

sp.speaker: Patroc.
sp.p: Thou mayst tell that know'st.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.p: O, tell, tell. This must be very foolish: aud I dye to have my spleen tickled.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: I'le decline the whole question. Agamemnon commands Achilles, Achilles is my Benefactor, I am Patroclus knower; and Patroclus is a fool.

sp.speaker: Patroc.
sp.p: You Rascal?

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.p: He's a priviledge'd man, proceed Thersites. Ha! ha! ha! prithee proceed while I am in the vein of laughing.

sp.speaker: Thersit.
sp.p: And all thses foresaid men are fools: Agamemnon's a fool to offer to command Achilles: Achilles is a fool to be commanded by him, I am a fool to serve such a fool, and Patroclus is a fool positive.

sp.speaker: Patroc.
sp.p: Why am I a fool?

sp.speaker: Thersi.
sp.p: Make that demand to Heaven, it suffices me thou art one.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! O give me ribs of steel, or I shall split with pleasure: now play me Nestor at a Night alarm: Mimick him rarely, make him cough and spet, and fumble with his gorget, and shake the rivits with his palsey hand; in and out, in and out, gad that's exceeding foolish.

sp.speaker: Patroc.
sp.p: Nestor shall not scape so, he has told us what we are; come what's Nestor?

sp.speaker: Thersi.
sp.p: Why he's an old wooden top, set up by father Time three hundred years ago, that hums to Agamemnon and Vlysses, and sleeps to all the world besides.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.p: So let him sleep for I'le no more of him: O my Patroclus, I but force a smile, Ajax has drawn the lot, and all the praise of Hector must be his.

sp.speaker: Thersi.
sp.p: I hope to see his praise upon his shoulders, in blows and bruises, his arms, thighs, and body, all full of fame; such fame as he gave me, and a wide hole at last full in his bosome, to let in day upon him, and discover the inside of a fool.

sp.speaker: Patroc.
sp.p: How he struts in expectation of honour! he knows not what he does.

sp.speaker: Thersi.
sp.p: Nay that's no wonder, for he never did.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.p: Prithee say how he behaves himself?

sp.speaker: Thersi.
sp.p:
O you would be learning to practice, against such another
time.— Why he tosses up his head as he had built Castles ith' ayr; and he treads upward to 'em, stalks into th'Element, he surveys himself, as 'twere to look for Ajax: he wou'd be cry'd, for he has lost himself, nay he knows no body; I said good morrow Ajax, and he replyed thanks Agamemnon.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.p: Thou shalt be my Ambassador to him Thersites.

sp.speaker: Thersi.
sp.p: No, I'le put on his person, let Patroclus make his demands to me, and you shall see the pageant of Ajax.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.p: To him Patroclus, tell him! humbly desire the valiant Ajax to invite the Noble Hector to my Tent: and to procure safe conduct for him from our Captain General Agamemnon.

sp.speaker: Patroc.
sp.p: Jove bless the mighty Ajax!

sp.speaker: Thersi.
sp.p: Humh!

sp.speaker: Patroc.
sp.p: I come from the great Achilles.

sp.speaker: Thersi.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Patroc.
sp.p: Who most humbly desires you to invite Hector to his Tent.

sp.speaker: Thersi.
sp.p: Humh!

sp.speaker: Patroc.
sp.p: And to procure him safe conduct from Agamemnon.

sp.speaker: Thersi.
sp.p: Agamemnon?

sp.speaker: Patroc.
sp.p: I, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Thersi.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.p: What say you to't?

sp.speaker: Therst.
sp.p: Farewell with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Patroc.
sp.p: Your answer Sir!

sp.speaker: Thersi.
sp.p: If to morrow be a fair day, by eleven a clock it will go one way or tother, however he shall buy me dearly, fare you well with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.p: Why but he is not in this tune is he?

sp.speaker: Thersi.
sp.p: No, but he's thus out of tune, what Musick will be in him when Hector has knocked out his brains I know not, nor I care not, but if emptiness makes noise, his head will make melody.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: My minde is troubled like a Fountain stir'd:
And I my self see not the bottom on't.

sp.speaker: Thersi.
sp.p: Wou'd the Fountain of his minde were clear; that he might see an Ass in't. [Aside.] I had rather be a tick in a sheep, than such a valiant ignorance.

sp.speaker: Patroc.
sp.p: Look who comes here.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.p: Patroclus, I'le speak with no body, come in after me Thersites.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.p: Where's Achilles!

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.p: Within, but ill dispos'd my Lord.

sp.speaker: Menel.
sp.p: We saw him at the opening of his Tent.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.p: Let it be known to him that we are here.

sp.speaker: Patroc.
sp.p: I shall say so to him.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.p: I know he is not sick.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: Yes, Lyon sick, sick of a proud heart, you may call it melancholy; if yo'll humour him: but on my 't tis no more than pride: and why shou'd he be proud?

sp.speaker: Menel.
sp.l: Here comes Patroclus; but no Achilles with him.

sp.speaker: Patroc.
sp.l: Achilles bids me tell you he is sorry
If any thing more than your sport and pleasure
Did move you to this visit: he's not well,
And begs you wou'd excuse him, as unfit
For present business.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: How! how's this Patroclus?
We are too well acquainted with these answers.
Though he has much desert, yet all his vertues
Do in our eyes begin to lose their gloss.
We came to speak with him; you shall not erre
If you return we think him over-proud
And under-honest. Tell him this; and adde,
That if he over-hold his price so much
We'll none of him: but let him like an Engine
Not portable, lye lagg of all the Camp.
A stirring Dwarf is of more use to us
Then is a sleeping Gyant; tell him so.

sp.speaker: Patroc.
sp.l: I shall; and bring his answer presently.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: I'le not be satisfi'd but by himself.
So tell him, Menelaus.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: What's he more than another?

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: No more than what he thinks himself.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: Is he so much! do you not think he thinks himself a better Man than me?

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.p: No doubt he does.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: Do you think so?

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.p: No, noble Ajax; you are as strong, as valiant; but much more courteous.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: Why shou'd a man be proud? I know not what pride is: I hate a proud man as I hate the ingendring of toads.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Aside. 'Tis strange he should; and love himself so well.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Achilles will not to the field to morrow.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: What's his excuse?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Why he relies on none
But his own will; possest he is with vanity:
What shou'd I say, he is so plaguy proud
That the death tokens of it are upon him;
And bode there's no recovery.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Let Ajax go to him.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: O Agamemnon, let it not be so.
We'll consecrate the steps that Ajax makes
When they go from Achilles: shall that proud man
Be worship'd by a greater than himself,
One whom we hold our Idoll;
Shall Ajax go to him? No, Jove forbid,
And say in thunder, go to him Achilles.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: [Aside.] O, this is well; he rubbs him where it itches.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: If I go to him with my Gantlet clench'd,
I'le dash him or'e the face.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: O no, you shall not go.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: And' he be proud with me I'le cure his pride: a paltry
Insolent fellow!

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: How he describes himself?

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.p: Aside. The crow chides blackness.— here is a man, but 'tis before his face, and therefore I am silent.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Wherefore are you? He is not envious as Achilles is.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: Know all the world he is as valiant.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: A whorson dogg that shall palter thus with us! wou'd a were a Trojan.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: Thank Heav'n my Lord, you're of a gentle nature,
Praise him that got you, her that brought you forth;
But he who taught you first the use of Armes,
Let Mars divide Eternity; in two,
And give him half. I will not praise your wisedome.
Nestor shall do't; but pardon father Nestor,
Were you as green as Ajax, and your brain
Temper'd like his, you never shou'd excell him;
But be as Ajax is.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: Shall I call you father?

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: I, my good Son.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Be rul'd by him Lord Ajax.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: There is no staying here; the Hart Achilles
Keeps thicket, please it our great General.
I shall impart a counsell, which observ'd
May cure this Madmans pride.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: In my own tent our talk will be more private.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: But nothing without Ajax:
He is the soul and substance of my councels
And I am but his shadow.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: You shall see
I am not like Achilles,
Let us confer; and I'le give counsel too.

div.head: SCENE II.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Come, come, what need you blush? shame's a babie; swear the oathes now to her, that you swore to me: what are you gone again? you must be watch'd ere you are made tame must you? why don't you speak to her first!— Come draw this Curtain, and lets see your picture: alas a day, how loath you are to offend day-light!— (they kisse) that's well, that's well, nay you shall fight your hearts out ere I part you.— so so— so so—

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.p: You have bereft me of all words, fair Cressida.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Words, pay no debts; give her deeds;— what billing again! here's in witness whereof the parties interchangeably— come in, come in, you lose time both.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.p: O Cressida, how often have I wish'd me here?

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.p: Wish'd my Lord!— the Gods grant! O my Lord.—

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.p: What shou'd they grant? what makes this pretty interruption in thy words?

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.p: speak I know not what!

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Speak ever so; and if I answer you
I know not what, it shews the more of love.
Love is a child that talks in broken language,
Yet then he speaks most plain.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.l: I finde it true, that to be wise and love
Are inconsistent things.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: what blushing still, have you not done talking vet!

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.l: Well Unkle, what folly I commit, I dedicate to you.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: I thank you for that: if my Lord get a boy of you, you'l give him me. Be true to my Lord, if he flinch Ile be hang'd for him— (Now am I in my kingdome!

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.p: You know your pledges now, your Unkles word and my firm faith.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Nay Ile give my word for her too: our kindred are constant: they are burrs I can assure you, they'll stick where they are thrown.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.l: Boldness comes to me now, and I can speak:
Prince Troylus, I have lov'd you long.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Why was my Cressida then so hard to win?

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.l: Hard to seem wonn; but I was wonn my Lord.
What have I blabb'd, who will be true to us,
When we are so unfaithfull to our selves!
O bid me hold my tongue? for in this rapture.
Sure I shall speak what I shou'd soon repent.
But stop my mouth.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: A sweet command; and willingly obey'd.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Pretty I faith!

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.l: My Lord I do beseech you pardon me,
'Twas not my purpose thus to beg a kisse.
I am asham'd: O heavens what have I done!
For thts time let me take my leave, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Leave! and you take leave till to morrow morning, call me Cut.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.l: Pray let me go.

sp.speaker: Troil,
sp.l: Why what offends you, Madam?

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.l: My own company.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: You cannot snun you self.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.l: Let me go and try:
I have a kind of self resides in you.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Oh that I thought truth cou'd be in a woman!
(As if it can, I will presume in you)
That my integrity and faith might meet
The same return form her who has my heart.
How shou'd I be exaltted! but alas
I am more plain then dull simplicity!
And art less, as the infancy of truth.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.l: In that I must not yield to you my Lord.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: All constant Lovers shall, in future Ages,
Approve their truth by Troylus: when their verse
Wants similes as turtles to their mates:
Or true as flowing tides are to the Moon;
Earth to the Center: Iron to Adamant:
At last when truth is tir'd with repetition;
As true as Troylus shall crown up the verse,
And sanctify the Numbers.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.l: Prophet my you be!
If I am false, or swerve from truth of love,
When time is old, and has forgot it self,
In all things else, let it remember me;
And after all comparisons of falshood
To stabb the heart of perjury in Maids;
Let it be said as false as Cressida.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Go to, little ones: a bargain made: here I hold your hand, and here my Cousins: if ever you prove false to one another, after I have taken such pains to bring you together: let all pitifull goers between, be call'd to the worlds end after my name, Pandars.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.l: And will you promise that the holy Priest
Shall make us one for ever!

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Priests! marry 'em! they make you one! go in, go in, and make your selves one without a priest: I'le have no priests work in my house.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: Ile not consent unless you swear.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: I, do, do, swear; a pretty woman's worth an oath at any time. Keep or break as time shall try; but 'tis good to swear, for the saving of her credit: Hang e'm sweet Rogues they never expect a Man shou'd keep it. Let him but swear, and that's all they care for.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Heavens prosper me as I devoutly swear,
Never to be but yours.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Whereupon I will lead you into a chamber: and suppose there be a bed in't; as I fack, I know not: but you'll forgive me, if there be: away, away, you naughty hildings: get ye together, get you together. Ah you wags, do you leer indeed at one another! do the neyes twinkle at him! get you together, get you together.

div.stage: Enoter at one door Aeneas with a Torch, at another Hector, Diomede with Torches,

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: So ho; who goes there? Aeneas!

sp.speaker: Aeneas.
sp.l: Prince Hector!

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Good morrow Lord Aeneas.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: A valiant Greek, Aeneas; take his hand;
Witnesse the processe of your speech within;
You told how Diomede a whole week by days
Did haunt you in the field.

sp.speaker: Aeneas.
sp.l: Health to you, valiant Sir,
During all business of the gentle truce;
But when I meet you arm'd, as black defiance
As heart can think, or courage execute.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Both one and to ther, Diomede embraces.
Our bloods are now in clam; and so, long health;
But when contention, and occasion meets,
By Jove I'le play the hunter for thy life,

sp.speaker: Eneas.
sp.l: And thou shalt hunt a Lyou that will fly
With his face backward: welcome Diomede
Welcome to Troy: now by Anchises Soul
No man alive can love in such a sort
The thing he means to kill, more excellently.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: We know eath other well.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: We do; and long to know each other worse
To Hect. my Lord, the King has sent for me in haste:
Know you the reason?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Yes: his purpose meets you,
It was to bring this Greek to Colchas's house.
Where Pandarus his Brother, and his Daughter
Fair Cressida reside: and there to render
For our Anthenor, now redeem'd from prison,
The Lady Cressida:

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: What! Has the King resolv'd to gratifie
That Traytor Colchos; who forsook his Country,
And turn'd to them, by giving up this pledge?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: The bitter disposition of the time
Is such, though Colchos as a fugitive
Deserve it not, that we must free Anthenor
On whose wise Counsels, we can most rely:
And therefore Cressida must be return'd.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: A word my Lord— (Your pardon Diomede)
Your Brother Troylus, to my certain knowledg,
Does lodge this night in Paudarus his house:

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Go you before: tell him of our approach
Which will I fear be much
Unwelcome to him.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: I assure you
Troylus had rather Troy were born to Greece
Than Cressida from Troy.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I know it well: and how he is beside,
Of hasty blood:

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: He will not hear me speak:
But I have noted long betwixt you two
A more than Brothers love: an awfull homage
The fiery youth pays to your elder vertue.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Leave it to me; I'le manage him alone:
Attend you Diomede; My Lord good morrow:
An urgent business takes me from the pleasure
Your company affords me; but Aeneas
With joy will undertake to serve you here,
And to supply my room.

sp.speaker: Aeneas.
sp.l: to Diomed. My Lord I wait you.

div.stage: [Diomede with Aeneas; Hector at another door.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Softly, villain, softly; I would not for half Troy the Lovers should be disturb'd under my roof; listen rogue, listen, do they breathe?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I hear by some certain signes, the are both awaken.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: That's as it shou'd be that's well aboth sides. [listens] Yes faith they are both alive:— there was a creake! there was a creake: they are both alive and alive like; there was a creake: a ha boyes!— Is the musick ready?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Shall they strike up Sir!

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Art thou sure they do not know the Parties?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: They play to the Man in the Moon for ought they know.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: To the Man in the Moon, ah Rogue! do they so indeed Rogue! I understand, thee: thou art a wag; thou art a wagg. Come towze rowze! in the name of love, strike up boys!

div.stage: Musick. and then Song: during which Pandarus listens.

lg.l: Can life be a blessing if love were away?
Ah no! though our love all night keep us waking,
And though he torment us with cares all the day,
yet he sweetens he sweetens our pains in the taking,
There's an hour at the last, there's an hour to repay.
In every possessing the fruit of our pain,
Poor lovers forget long ages of anguish,
Whate're they have suffer'd and done to obtain;
'Tis a pleasure, a pleasure to sigh and to languish,
When we hope, when we hope to be happy again.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Put up, and vanish; they are coming out; what a ferrup, will you play when the dance is done? I say vanish.

sp.speaker: Peeping.
sp.p: Good Ifaith; good ifarth! what hand in hand!— a fair quarrell, well ended! do, do, walk him, walk him; A good girl, a discreet girl: I see she'll make the most of him.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Farewell, my life! leave me and back to bed:
Sleep seal those pretty eyes;
And tye thy sences in as soft a band
As Infants voyd of thought.

sp.speaker: Pandar.
sp.p: shewing himself. How now, how now, how go matters! hear you Maid, hear you; where's my Cousin Cressida?

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.l: Go hang your self you naughty mocking Unkle:
You bring me to do ill and then you jeere me!

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: What ill have I brought you to do? say what if you dare now!
My Lord have I brought her to do ill?

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.p: Come, come, beshrew your heart; you'll neither be good your self, nor suffer others.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Alas poor wench; alas poor Devil; hast not slept to night? wou'd anot (a naughty Man) let it sleep one twinkle! Ah bugbear take him!

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.l: Who's that at door? good Uncle go and see:
My Lord come you again into my chamber!
You smile and mock as if I meant naughtily!

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Indeed, indeed!

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.l: Come y'are deceiv'd; I think of no such thing:
How earnestly they knock, pray come in:
I wou'd not for all Troy, you were seen here.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Who's there! whats the matter!
Will you beat down the house there!

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Good morrow my Lord Pandarus; good morrow!

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Who's there, Prince Hector! what news with you so early?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Is not my Brother Troilus here?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Here! what shou'd he do here?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Come he is here my Lord, do not deny him:
It does import him much to speak with me.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Is he here say you? 'tis more than I know, I'le be sworn!
For my own part I came in late!— what shou'd he do here?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: Come, come you do him wrong ere y'are aware; you'll be so true to him, that you'll be false to him: you shall not know he's here; but yet go fetch him hither:— goe.
sp.l: I bring you Brother, most unwelcome news;
But since of force you are to hear it told,
I thought a friend and Brother best might tell it:
Therefore, befroe I speak, arm well your mind
And think y'are to be touch'd dev'n to the quick;
That so, prepar'd for ill you may be less
Surpris'd to hear the worst.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: See Hector, what it is to be your Brother,
I stand prepar'd already.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Come, you are not,
I know you Troilus, you are hot and fiery:
You kindle at a wrong; and catch it quick
As stubble does the flame.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: 'Tis heat of blood
And rashness of my youth. I'le mend that errour:
Begin and try my temper.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Can you think
Of that one thing which most cou'd urge your anger
Drive you to madness, plunge you in despair,
And make you hate ev'n me?

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: There can be nothing.
I love you Brother, with that awful love
I bear to Heav'n, and to superior vertue,
And when I quit this love you must be that
Which Hector near can be.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Remember well
What you have said: for when I claim your promise
I shall expect performance.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: I am taught:
I will not rage.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Nor grieve beyond a man.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: I won not be a woamn.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Do not Brother:
And I will tell my news, in terms so mild,
So tender, and so fearful to offend
As Mothers use to sooth their froward Babes;
Nay I will swear as you hve sworn to me,
That if some gust of passion swell your soul
To words intemperate, I will bear with you.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: What wou'd this pomp of preparation mean?
Come you to bring me news of Priams death
Or Hecuba's

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: The Gods forbid I shou'd:
But what I bring is nearer you, more close,
An ill more yours,

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: There is but one that can be.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Perhaps 'tis that.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: I'le not suspect my fate
So far, I know I stand possest of that.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: 'Tis well: consider at whose house I finde you.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Does it start you! I must wake you more:
Anthenor is exchang'd.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: For whom.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Imagine.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: It comes like thunder grumbling in a cloud,
Before the dreadfull break: if here it fall,
The subtile flame will lick up all my blood,
And in a moment turn my heart to ashes.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: That Cressida for for Anthenor is exchang'd
Because I knew 'twas harsh I wou'd not tell;
Not all at once; but by degrees and glimpses
I let it in, lest it might rush upon you
And quite orepower your Soul: in this I think
I show'd a friend: your part must follow next:
Which is, to curb your choler, tame your grief,
And bear it like a man.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: I think I do
That I yet live to hear you: but no more:
Hope for no more: for shou'd some Goddess offer
To give her self and all her Heaven in change,
I wou'd not part with Cressida: so return
This answer as my last.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: 'Twill not be taken:
Nor will I bear such news.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: You bore me worse.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Worse for your self; not for the general state,
And all our common fafety, which depends
On free'd Anthenors wisdome.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: You wou'd say
That I'm the Man mark'd out to be unhappy;
And made the publick Sacrifice for Troy.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I wou'd say so indeed: for can you finde
A fate more glorious than to be that victime?
If parting from a Mistriss can procure
A Nations happiness, show me that Prince
Who dares to trust his future fame so farr
To stand the shock of Annals, blotted thus
He sold his Country for a womans love?

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: O, she's my life, my being, and my Soul!

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Suppose she were, which yet I will not grant,
You ought to give her up.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: For whom!

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: The publick.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: And what are they that I shou'd give up her
To make them happy? let me tell you Brother,
The publick, is the Lees of vulgar slaves:
Slaves, with the minds of slaves: so born, so bred:
Yet such as these united in a herd
Are call'd the publique: Millions of such Cyphers
Make up the publique sum: an Eagles life
Is worth a world of Crows: are Princes made
For such as these, who, were one Soul extracted
From all their beings, cou'd not raise a Man.—

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: And what are we, but for such men as these?
'Tis adoration, some say makes a God:
And who shou'd pay it, where wou'd be their Altars
Were no inferiour creatures here on Earth?
Ev'n those who serve have their expectances;
Degrees of happiness, which they must share,
Or they'll refuse to serve us.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Let e'm have it.
Let e'm eat, drink and sleep; the only use
They have of life:

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: You take all these away,
Unless you give up Cressida.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Forbear;
Let Paris give up Hellen: she 's the cause,
And root of all this mischief.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Your own suffrage
Condemns you there: you voted for her stay.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: If one must stay, the other sha'not go.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: She sha'not?

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Once again, I say she shall not.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Our Father has decree'd it otherwise.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: No matter.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: How! no matter Troylus?
A King, and fathers will!

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: When 'tis unjust.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Come she shall go.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: She shall? then I am dar'd.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: If nothing else will do.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Answer me first;
And then Ile answer that: be sure I will;
Whose hand seal'd this exchange?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: My Fathers first;
Then all the Council's after.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Was yours there?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Mine was there too.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Then you'r no more my friend:
And for your sake now mark me what I say,
She shall not go.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Go to, you are a boy,

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: A Boy! Im'e glad I am not such a Man,
Not such as thou; a traytor to thy Brother:
Nay more, thy friend: but friend's a Sacred name,
Which none but brave and honest men shou'd wear;
In thee 'tis vile; 'tis prostitute: 'tis Ayr;
And thus I puffe it from me.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Well, young Man,
Since I'me no friend (and oh that ere I was
To one so far unworthy) bring her out,
Or by our Fathers Soul, of which no part
Did ere descend to thee, Ile force her hence.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: I laugh at thee.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Thou dar'st not.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: I dare more,
If urg'd beyond my temper: prove my daring,
And see which of us has the larger share
Of our great Fathers Soul.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: No more, thou knowst me.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: I do; and know my self.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: All this ye Gods,
And for the Daughter of a fugitive,
A Traytor to his Country!

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: 'Tis too much.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: By Heaven too little; for I think her common,

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: How, Common!

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Common as the tainted shambles,
Or as the dust we tread.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: By Heaven as chaste as thy Andromache.

div.stage: Hector lays his hand on Troylus his Arm; and Troylus does the same to him.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: What! nam'st thou them together!

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: No; I do not:
For Cressida is first: as chaste as she,
But much more fair.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: O patience, patience, Heaven!
Thou tempt'st me strangely: shou'd I kill thee now,
I know not if the Gods can be offended
Or think I slew a Brother; but be gone,
Be gone, or I shall shake thee into Atomes:
Thou know'st I can.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: I care not if you cou'd.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: walking off. I thank ye Gods for calling to my minde
My promise that no words of thine shou'd urge me,
Beyond the bounds of reason: But in thee
'Twas brutall baseness, so forewarn'd to fall
Beneath the name of man: to spurn my kindness;
And when I offer'd thee (thou knowst how loth!)
The wholsome bitter cup o' friendly counsel.
To dash it in my face: farewel, farewel.
Ungratefull as thou art: hereafter use
The name of Brother; but of friend no more.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Wilt thou not break yet heart? stay Brother, stay.
I promis'd too, but I have broke my vow,
And you keep yours too well.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: What wouldst thou more?
Take heed, young man how you too far provoke me!
For Heaven can witness 'tis with much constraint
That I preserve my faith.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Else you wou'd kill me;

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: By all the Gods I wou'd.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: I'me satisfi'd.
You have condemn'd me, and Ile do't my self;
What's life to him, who has no use of life?
A barren purchase, held upon hard terms!
For I have lost (oh what have I not lost!)
The fairest, dearest, kindest of her Sex,
And lost her ev'n by him, by him, ye Gods,
Who only cou'd, and only shou'd protect me!
And if I had a joy beyond that love,
A friend, have lost him too!

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Speak that again:
(For I cou'd hear it ever:) saidst thou not
That if thou hadst a joy beyond that love
It was a friend? O saydst thou not a friend!
That doubting if was kinde: then thou'rt divided;
And I have still some part,

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: If still you have
You do not care to have it.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: How, not care!

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: No, Brother, care not.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Am I but thy Brother!

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: You told me I I must call you friend no more.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: How far my words were distant from my heart!
Know when I told thee so I lov'd thee most.
Alas! it is the use of human frailty
To fly to worst extremities with those
To whom we most are kind.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Is't possible!
Then you are still my friend!

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Heaven knows I am!

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: And can forgive the Sallies of my passion?
For I have been too blame: oh much too blame:
Have said such words, nay done such actions too,
(Base as I am) that my aw'd, conscious Soul
Sinks in my breast, nor dare I lift an eye
On him I have offended.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Peace be to thee
And calmness ever there. I blame thee not:
I know thou lov'st; and what can love not do!
I cast the wild disorderly account
Of all thy words and deeds on that mad passion;
I pity thee, indeed I pity thee:

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Do; for I need it: let me lean my head
Upon thy bosome; all my peace dwells there;
Thou art some God, or much much more then man!

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Alas! to lose the joys of all thy youth,
One who deserv'd thy love!

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Did she deserve?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: She did.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Then sure she was no common creature.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I said it in my rage, I thought not so.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: That thought has bles'd me! but to lose this love.
After long pains, and after short possession.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I feel it for thee: Let me go to Priam,
I'le break this treaty off; or let me fight;
I'le be thy champion; and secure both her
And thee, and Troy.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: It must not be, my Brother!
For then your errour would be more then mine:
I'le bring her forth, and you shall bear her hence;
That you have pitied me is my reward.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Go then; and the good gods restore her to thee,
And with her all the quiet of thy minde;
The triumph of this kindeness be thy own;
And heaven and earth this testimony yield,
That Friendship never gain'd a nobler field.

div.head: ACT IV. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: I'St possible! no sooner got but lost!
The devil take Antenor: the young Prince will go mad:
A plague upon Anthenor! wou'd they had broke's neck.

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: How now! what's the matter! who was here!

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: Why sigh you so! O where's my Troilus? tell me sweet
Uncle what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Wou'd I were as deep under the earth, as I am above it!

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: Oh the Gods, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Prithee get thee in, wou'd thou hadst never been born!
I knew thou woud'st be his death; oh poor Gentleman!
A plague upon Antenor?

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.p: Good Uncle, I beseech you on my knees, tell me what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Thou must be gone girl; thou must be gone, to the fugitive Rogue Priest thy father, (and he's my brohter too, but that's all one at this time:) a pox upon Antenor.?

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: O ye immortal Gods, I will not go.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Thou must, thou must?

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: I will not: I have quite forgot my father;
I have no touch of birth; no spark of Nature:
No kinn, no blood, no life; nothing so near me
As my dear Troilus?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Here, here, here, he comes sweet Duck!

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: O Troilus, Troilus!

div.stage: [They both weep over each other, she running into his armes.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: What a pair of Spectacles is here! let me embrace too: Oh heart, sings (as the saying is) O heart, heavy heart, why sighst thou without breaking (where he answers again) because thou canst not ease thy smart, by friendship nor by speaking, there was never a truer rhime; let us cast away nothing; for we may live to have need of such a verse: we see it; we see it, how now lambs?

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Cressida, I love thee with so strange a purity
That the blest Gods, angry with my devotions
More bright in zeal, than that I pay their Altars,
Will take thee from my sight?

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: Have the Gods envy?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: I, I, I, 'tis too plain a case!

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: And is it true, that I must go from Troy?

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: A hastefull truth?

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: What, and from Troilus too?

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: From Troy and Troilus: and suddenly.
So suddenly 'tis counted but by minutes.

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: What not an hour allow'd for taking leave?

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Ev'n that's bereft us too: our envious fates
Justle betwixt, and part the dear adieus
Of meeting lips, clasp'd hands, and lock'd embraces.
My Lord, is the Lady ready yet?

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Hark, you are call'd: some say the Genius so
Cryes come, to him who instantly must dye.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Where are my tears! some rain to'lay this wind:
Or my heart will be blown up by th' roots!

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Hear me my Love! be thou but true like me.

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: I true! how now, what wicked thought is this?

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Nay, we must use expostulation kindly,
For it is parting from us:
I spoke not, be thou true, as fearing thee;
But be thou true, I said to introduce
My following protestation: be thou true,
And I will see thee.

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: You'll be expos'd to dangers.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: I care not: but be true.

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: Be true again?

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Hear why I speak it love.
The Grecian Youths are full of Grecian Arts:
Alas a kind of holy jealousie
Which I beseech you call a vertuous sin,
Makes me afraid how far you may be tempted.

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: O Heavens, you love me not!

sp.speaker: Troil
sp.l: Dye I, a villain then!
In this I do not call your faith in question
But my own merit.

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: Fear not; I'le be true

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Then fate thy worst; for I will see thee love
Not all the Grecian host shall keep me out,
Nor Troy, though wall'd with fire, shou'd hold me in.
My Lord, my Lord Troilus: I must call you.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p:
A mischief call him: nothing but Schreechowls? do, do, call again; you had best part 'em now in the sweetnesse of their love! I'le be hang'd if this Aeneas be the Son of Venus, for all his bragging.
Honest Venus was a Punk: wou'd she have parted Lovers: no he has not a drop of Venus blood in him: honest Venus was a Punk.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: To Pand. Prithee go out; and gain one minute more.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Marry and I will: follow you your business; lose no time, 'tis very precious; go, Bill again: I'le tell the Rogue his own I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: What have we gain'd by this one minute more?

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Only to wish another, and another
A longer struggling with the pangs of death.

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: O those who do not know what parting is
Can never learn to dye!

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: When I but think this sight may be our last,
If Jove cou'd set me in the place of Atlas
And lay the weight of Heav'n and Gods upon me
He cou'd not presse me more.

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: Oh let me go that I may know my grief;
Grief is but guess'd, while thou art standing by:
But I too soon shall know what absence is.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Why 'tis to be no more: another name for death.
'Tis the Sunn parting from the frozen North;
And I, me thinks, stand on some cey cliff,
To watch the last low circles that he makes;
Till he sink down from Heav'n! O only Cressida,
If thou depart from me, I cannot live:
I have not soul enough to last for grief,
But thou shalt hear what grief has done with me.

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: If I could live to hear it, I were false,
But as a careful traveller who fearing
Assaults of Robbers, leaves his wealth behind,
I trust my heart with thee; and to the Greeks
Bear but an empty Casket.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Then, I will live; that I may keep that treasure:
And arm'd with this assurance, let thee go
Loose, yet secure as is the gentle Hawk
When whistled off she mounts into the wind,
Our love's, like Mountains high above the clouds,
Though winds and tempests beat their aged feet,
Their peaceful heads nor storm nor thunder know,
But scorn the threating rack that roles below,

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Achilles and Patroclus, standing in their Tent.
Ulysses, Agamemnon, Menelaus, Nestor, Ajax, passing over the Stage.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: AChilles stands in th'entrance of his Tent:
Please it our General to pass strangely by him,
As if he were forgot, and Princes all
Look on him with neglectful eyes and scorn:
Pride must be cur'd by pride.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: We'll execute your purpose, and put on
A form of strangness as we pass along
So do each Prince either salute him not
Or else disdainfully, which will shake him more
Then if not look'd on: I will lead the way.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: What, comes the General to speak with me!
You know my mind; I'll fight no more with Troy.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: What says Achilles, wou'd he ought with us?

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Wou'd you, my Lord, ought with the General!

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Nothing my Lord.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: The better.

sp.speaker: Menel.
sp.l: How do you, how do you!

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: What does the Cuckold scorn me!

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: How now Patroclus!

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: Good morrow Ajax.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: Good morrow.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: I; and good next day too.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: What mean these fellows! know they not Achilles?

sp.speaker: Patroc.
sp.l: They pass by strangely; they were us'd to bow;
And send their smiles before 'em to Achilles,
To come as humbly as they us'd to creep, to holy Altars.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: Am I poor of late!
'Tis certain, greatness once fall'n out with fortune
Must fall out with men too! what the declind is
He shall as soon read in the eyes of others
As feel in his own fall: for men like butter-flyes,
Show not their mealy wings but to the Summer.

sp.speaker: Patroc.
sp.l: 'Tis known you are in love with Hector's Sister,
And therefore will not fight: and your not fighting
Draws on you this contempt: I oft have told you
A woman impudent and mannish grown
Is not more loath'd than an effeminate man,
In time of action: I'm condemn'd for this:
They think my little appetite to warr
Deads all the fire in you: but rowse your self,
And love shall from your neck unloose his folds;
Or like a dew drop from a Lyons Mane
Be shaken into ayr.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: Shall Ajax fight with Hector?

sp.speaker: Patrocl.
sp.l: Yes, and perhaps shall gain much honour by him.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: I see my reputation is at stake.

sp.speaker: Patroc.
sp.p: O then beware, those wounds heal ill that men have giv'n themselves, because they give e'm deepest.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: I'le do something:
But what I know not yet,— No more our Champion.

div.stage: Re-enter Ajax, Agamemnon, Menelaus, Ulysses, Nest. Diomede, Trumpet

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Here art thou daring combat, valiant Ajax.
Give with thy Trumpet, a loud note to Troy,
Thou Noble Champion, that the sounding ayr
May pierce the ears of the great challenger,
And call him hither.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: Trumpet take that purse:
Now crack thy lungs, and split the sounding brass;
Thou blow'st for Hector.

div.stage: [Trumpet sounds, and is answer'd from within.
Enter Hector, Aeneas, and other Trojans.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Yonder comes the Troop.
Health to the Grecian Lords; what shall be done
To him that shall be vanquish'd? or do you purpose,
A Victor should be known! will you the Knights,
Shall to the edg of all extremity,
Pursue each other, or shall be divided
By any voice or order of the field;
Hector bad ask.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Which way won'd Hector have it?

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: He cares not, he'll obey conditions.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: 'Tis done like Hector but securely done;
A little proudly, and too much dispising
The Knight oppos'd, he might have found his match.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: If not Achilles, Sir, what is your name!

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: If not Achilles nothing.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Therefore Achilles, but who ere know this;
Great Hector knows no pride, weigh him but well,
And that which looks like pride is courtesy.
This Ajax is half made of Hectors blood,
In love whereof half Hector stays at home;

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: A Maiden battle! I perceive you then.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Go Diomede, and stand by valiant Ajax:
As you and Lord Aeneas shall consent,
So let the fight proceed or terminate.

div.stage: [The Trumpets sound on both sides, while Aeneas and Diomede take their places, as Iudges of the Field: The Trojans and Grecians rank themselves on either side.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: They are oppos'd already.
sp.stage: [Fight equal at first, then Ajax has Hector at disadvantage: at last Hector closes, Ajax falls on one knee, Hector stands over him but striks not, and Ajax rises.
Aeneas throwing his Gauntlet betwixt them.
sp.l: Princes enough, you both have shown much valour.

sp.speaker: Diomede.
sp.l: And we as Judges of the Field declare;
The combat here shall cease.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: I am not warm yet, let us fight again.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Then let it be as Hector shall determine.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: If it be left to me, I will no more.

sp.speaker: Ajax,
sp.l: thou art my Aunt Hesion's Son;
The Obligation of our blood forbids us.
But were thy mixture Greek and Trojan so,
That thou cou'dst say, this part is Grecian all
And this is Trojan, hence thou shou'dst not bear
One Grecian limb, wherein my pointed Sword
Had not impression made, but Heav'n forbid
That any drop thou borrowst from my Mother,
Shou'd ere be drained by me, let me embrace thee Cousin:
By him who thunders thou hast sinnewy arms,
Hector wou'd have 'em fall upon him thus:—
Thine be the honour, Ajax.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: I thank thee Hector,
Thou art too gentle, and too free a Man:
I came to kill thee Cousin, and to gain
A great addition from that glorious act:
But thou hast quite disarm'd me.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I am glad.
For 'tis the only way I cou'd disarm thee.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: If I might in intreaty finde success,
I wou'd desire to see thee at my Tent.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: 'Tis Agamemnons wish, and great Achilles,
Both long to see the valiant Hector there.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Aeneas, call my Brother Troilus to me;
And you two signe this friendly enterview.

div.stage: [Agamemnon, and the cheif of both sides approch.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: to Hect. Worthy of Arms, as welcome as to one
Who wou'd be rid of such an Enemy.
To Troil. My well fam'd Lord of Troy, no less to you.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: I have, thou gallant Trojan seen thee often
Labouring for destiny, make cruel way,
Through ranks of Grecian youth, and I have seen thee
As swift as lightning spur thy Phrygian Steed,
And seen thee scorning many forfeit lives,
When thou hast hung thy advanc'd Sword ith' ayr,
Not leting it decline, on prostrate foes:
That I have said to all the standers by
Lo Jove is yonder, distributing life.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Let me embrace thee, good old Chroni le,
Who hast so long walkt hand in hand with time:
Most Reverend Nestor, I am glad to clasp thee.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: I wonder now, how yonder City stands,
When we have here, her base and pillar by us.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I know your count'nance, Lord Vlysses well;
Ah Sir, there's many a Greek and Trojan dead,
Since first I saw your self and Diomede,
In Ilion, on your Greekish Embassy.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: Now Hector, I have fed mine eyes on thee;
I have with exact view perus'd thee Hector,
And quoted joint by joint.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Is this Achilles!

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: I am Achilles.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Stand fair, I prithee let me look on thee.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: Behold thy fill.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Nay, I have done already.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: Thou art too brief, I will the second time
As I wou'd buy thee, view thee limb by limb.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: O, like a Book of sport thou read'st me ore;
But there's more in me then thou understand'st.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: Tell me ye Heav'ns, in which part of his body
Shall I destroy him? there, or there, or there!
That I may give th'imagin'd wound a name,
And make distinct the very breach, whereout
Hectors great spirit flew! answer me Heavens!

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Wert thou an Oracle to tell me this!
I'de not believe thee, henceforth guard thee well,
I'le kill the every where:
Ye Noble Grecians pardon me this boast,
His insolence draws folly from my lips,
But I'le endeavour deeds to match these words;
Else may I never.—

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: Do not chafe thee Cousin,
And you Achilles let these threats alone:
You may have every day enough of Hector,
If you have stomack, the General State I fear
Can scarce intreat you to perform your boast.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I pray you let us see you in the field;
