We have had paltry Wars, since you refus'd
The Grecian cause.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: Dost thou entreat me Hector!
To morrow will I meet thee fierce as death;
To Night all peace.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Thy hand upon that match.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: First all you Grecian Princes go with me,
And entertain great Hector, afterwards,
As his own leasure, shall concur with yours,
You may invite him to your several Tents.

div.stage: [Exeunt Agam. Hect. Menel. Nestor, Diomede, together.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: My Lord Vlysses.

div.l: Tell me I beseech you;
In what part of the field does Calehas lodg!

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: At Menelaus Tent;
There Diomede does feast with him to Night:
Who neither looks on Heaven or on Earth,
But gives all gaze and bent of amorous view,
On Cressida alone.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Shall I, brave Lord be bound to you so much
After we part from Agamemnons Tent.
To bring me thither!

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: I shall want on you.
As freely tell me, of what honour was
This Cressida in Troy? had she no Lovers there
Who mourn her absence?

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: O Sir, to such as boasting show their scars,
Reproof is due, she lov'd and was belov'd:
That's all I must impart. Lead on my Lord.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: to Patro. I'le heat his blood with Greckish wine to Night,
Which with my Sword I mean to cool to morrow.
Patroclus, let us feast him to the height.

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.l: Here comes Thersites.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: How now thou core of envy,
Thou crusty batch of Nature, what's the news?

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.l: Why thou picture of what thou seemst, thou Idoll of
Ideot worshippers, there's a Letter for thee.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: From whence fragment?

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.l: Why thou full dish of fool, from Troy.

sp.speaker: Patroc.
sp.l: Well said adversity! what makes thee so keen to day?

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.l: Because a fool's my whetstone.

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.l: Meaning me?

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: Yes meaning thy no meaning; prithee be silent, boy, I profit not by thy talk: Now the rotten diseases of the South, gut gripings, ruptures, Catarrhs; loads of gravell in the back, Lethargies, cold palsies, and the like, take thee, and take thee again; thou green Sarcenet flap for a sore eye, thou tassell of a prodigals purse, thou: Ah how the poor world is pester'd with such water-flys: such diminitives of nature.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: My dear Patroclus, I am quite prevented
From my great purpose, bent on Hector's life:
Here is a Letter from my love Polixena,
Both taxing, and ingaging me to keep
An Oath that I have sworn: and will not break it
To save all Greece: let honour go or stay,
There's more Religion in my love than fame:

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: With too much blood, and too little brain, these two are running mad before the dog-days. There's Agamemnon too, an honest fellow enough, and loves a brimmer heartily; but he has not so much brains as an old gander. But his brother Menelaus, there's a fellow: the goodly transformation of Jupiter when he lov'd Europa: the primitive Cuckold: A vile Monkey ty'd eternally to his brothers table. To be a Dog, a Mule, a Cat, a toad, an Owle, a Lizard, a Herring without a roe, I would not care: but to be Menelaus I would conspire against destiny— Hey day! will with a wispe, and Jack a lanthorn!

div.stage: Hector, Ajax, Agamemnon, Diomede, Ulisses, Troilus, going with torches over the stage.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: We go wrong; we go wrong.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: No, yonder 'tis; there where see the light.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I touble you.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: Not at all Cousin: Here comes Achilles himself to guide us.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: Welcome brave Hector, welcome princes all:

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: So now, brave Prince of Tray, I take my leave;
Ajax commands the guard, to wait on you.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Good night my Lord!

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Good night Sweet Lord Menelaus.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: aside. Sweet quoth a! sweet Sink, sweet shore, sweet Jakes!

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: Nestor will stay; and you Lord Diomede.
Keep Hector company an hour or two.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: I cannot Sir: I have important business.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: Enter my Lords.

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.l: to Troil. Follow his torch: he goes to Calchas's tent.

div.stage: [Exeunt Achill. Hect. Ajax at one way, Diomede, another; and after him Ulyss, Troylus.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: This Diomede's a most false-hearted rogue, an unjust Knave: I will no more trust him when he winks with one eye, then I will a Serpent when he hisses. He will spend his mouth and promise, like Brabbler the Hound: but when he performs, Astronomers set it down for a prodigy; Though I long to see Hector, I cannot forbear dogging him. They say a keeps a Trojan Drabb: and uses Calchas tent, that fugitive Priest of Troy; that Canonical Rogue of our side. I'le after him: nothing but whoring in this Age: all incontinent Rascalls!

sp.speaker: Calch.
sp.l: O, what a blessing is a vertuous child!
Thou hast reclam'd my mind, and calm'd my passions
Of anger and revenge: my love to Troy
Revives within me, and my lost Tyara
No more disturbs my mind:

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.l: A vertuous conquest.

sp.speaker: Calch.
sp.l: I have a womans longing to return
But yet which way without your ayd I know not.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.l: Time must instruct us how.

sp.speaker: Calch.
sp.l: You must dissemble love to Diomede still
False Diomede, bred in Vlysses School
Can never be deceiv'd,
But by strong Arts and blandishments of love:
Put 'em in practice all: seem lost and won,
And draw him on, and give him line again.
This Argus then may close his hundred eyes
And leave our flight more easy.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.l: How can I answer this to love and Troilus?

sp.speaker: Calch.
sp.l: Why 'tis for him you do it: promise largely;
That Ring he saw you wear, he much suspects
Was given you by a Lover; let him have it.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: within. Hoa; Calchas, Calchas!

sp.speaker: Calch.
sp.l: Hark! I hear his voice.
Pursue your project: doubt not the success.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.l: Heaven knows against my will: and yet my hopes
This night to meet my Triolus, while 'tis truce
Afford my minde some ease.

sp.speaker: Calch.
sp.l: No more: retire.

div.stage: Enter Diomede; Troilus and Ulysses appear listening at one door, and Thersites watching at another.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: I came to see your Daughter, worthy Calchas.

sp.speaker: Calch.
sp.l: My Lord I'le call her to you.

sp.speaker: Vlysses
sp.l: to Troil. Stand where the torch may not discover us.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Cressida comes forth to him!

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: How now my charge?

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.l: Now my sweet Guardian: hark a word with you.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: I, so familiar!

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Will you remember?

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.l: Remember: yes.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Heav'ns! what shou'd she remember! plague and madnesse!

sp.speaker: Vlysses.
sp.l: Prince, you are mov'd: let us depart in time
Lest your displeasure should enlarge it self
To wrathfull terms: this place is dangerous;
The time unfit: ' beseech you let us go.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: I pray you stay; by Hell, and by Hell torments
I will not speak a word.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: I'le hear no more: good night.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.l: Nay, but you part in anger!

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Does that grieve thee! O wither'd truth!

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Farewell Cousner.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.l: Indeed I am not: pray come back again.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: You shake my Lord, at something: will you go?
You will break out.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: By all the Gods I will not.
There is between my will and all my actions,
A guard of patience! stay a little while.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: aside. How the devill luxury with his fat rump, and potato finger, tickles these together! put him off a little, you foolish Harlot! 'twill sharpen him the more.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: But will you then?

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: I will as soon as ere the War's concluded.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Give me some token, for the surety of it:
The Ring I saw you wear.

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: Giving it. If you must have it.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: The Ring! nay then 'tis plain! O beauty where's thy faith!

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: You have sworn patience.

sp.speaker: Thersi.
sp.p: That's well, that's well, the pledge is given, hold her to her word good Devil and her soul's thine I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Who's wast?

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: By all Diana's waiting train of stars,
And by her self, I will not tell you whose.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Why then thou lov'st him still, farewell for ever:
Thou never shalt mock Diomede again.

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: You shall not go, one cannot speak a word
But straight it starts you.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: I do not like this fooling.

sp.speaker: Thersi.
sp.l: Nor I by Pluto: but that which likes not me, pleases me best.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: I shall expect your promise.

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: I'le perform it.
Not a word more, good night—- I hope for ever:
Thus to deceive deceivers is no fraud.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: All's done my Lord.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Is it?

sp.speaker: vlyss.
sp.l: Pray let us go.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Was Cressida here?

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: I cannot conjure Trojan.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: She was not sure! she was not.
Let it not be believ'd for womanhood:
Think we had Mothers, do not give advantage,
To biting Satyr, apt without a theme,
For defamation, to square all the sex
By Cressid's rule rather think this not Cressida.

sp.speaker: Thersi.
sp.l: Will he swagger himself out on 's own eyes!

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: This she! no this was Diomedes Cessida.
If beauty have a Soul, this is not she:
I cannot speak for rage, that Ring was mine,
By Heaven I gave it, in that point of time
When both our joys were fullest!— if he keeps it
Let dogs eat Troilus.

sp.speaker: Thersi.
sp.p: He'll tickle it for his Concupy: this will be sport to see!

Patroclus will give me any thing for the intelligence of this whore; a parrot will not do more for an almond, than he will for a commodious drab: I would I cou'd meet with this Rogue Diomede too; I wou'd croke like a Raven to him; I wou'd bode: it shall go hard but I 'le find him out.

sp.speaker: Aen.
sp.l: I have been seeking you this hour, my Lord:
Hector by this is arming him in Troy.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: Commend me gallant Troilus to your Brother:
Tell him I hope he shall not need to arm:
The fair Polixena has by a letter
Disarm'd our great Achilles of his rage.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: This I shall say to Hector.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: So I hope!
Pray Heaven Thersites have inform'd me true,—

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Good night, my Lord; accept distracted thanks.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Hear ye, my Lord, hear ye; I have been seeing yon poor girl.
There have been old doings there i'faith.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: aside. Hold yet, my Spirits; let him powr it in:
The poyson's kind: the more I drink of it
The sooner 'twill dispatch me.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: to Pand. Peace you babbler!

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: She has been mightily made on by the Greeks: she takes most wonderfully among em: Achilles kiss'd her, and Patroclus Kiss'd her: Nay and old Nestor put aside his gray beard and brush'd her with his whiskers. Then comes me Agamemnon with his Generals Staff, diving with a low bow e'en to the ground, and rising again, just at her lips: And after him came Vlysses, and Ajax, and Menelaus: and they so pelted her i'faith: pitter patter, pitter patter, as thick as hayl-stones. And after that a whole rout of 'em: Never was woman in Phrygia better kiss'd.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.p: aside. Hector said true: I finde, I finde it now!

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: And last of all comes me Diomede so demurely: that's a notable sly Rogue I warrant him! mercy upon us, how he layd her on upon the lips! for as I told you, she's most mightily made on among the Greekes. What, cheer up I say Man! she has every ones good word. I think in my conscience, she was born with a caull upon her head.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: aside. Hell, death, confusion, how he tortures me!

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: And that Rogue-Priest my Brother, is so courted and treated for her sake: the young Sparks do so pull him about, and hall him by the Cassock: nothing but invitations to his Tent, and his Tent, and this Tent. Nay and one of'em was so bold, as to ask him if she were a Virgin, and with that the Rogue my Brother, takes me up a little God in his hand, and kisses it; and swears devoutly that she was, then was I ready to burst my sides with laughing, to think what had pass'd betwixt you two.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: O I can bear no more: she's falshood all:
False by both kinds; for with her mothers milk
She suck'd th'infusion of her Fathers Soul.
She only wants an opportunity,
Her Soul's a whore already.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: What wou'd you make a Monopoly of a womans lips: a little consolation or so, might be allow'd one wou'd think in a lovers absence!

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Hence from my sight: let ignominy brand thy hated name:
Let Modest Matrons at thy mention start;
And blushing Virgins, when they read our Annals,
Skipo're the guilty page that holds thy Legend,
And blots the noble work.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: O world, world; thou art an ungratefull patch of Earth!

Thus the poor Agent is despis'd! he labours painfully in his calling, and trudges between parties: but when their turns are serv'd, come out's too good for him. I am mighty melancholy: I'le e'en go home, and shut up my doors; and dye o'th sullens like an old bird in a Cage!

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: aside. There; there he is: now let it work: now play thy part jealousy, and twinge e'm: put 'em between thy milstones, and grinde the Rogues together.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: My Lord I am by Ajax sent to infrom you
This hour muft end the truce.

sp.speaker: Aeneas
sp.l: to Troil. Contain your self;
Think where we are.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Your stay will be unsafe.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: It may for those I hate.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.l: aside. Well said Trojan: there's the frrst hit.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Beseech you Sir make haste, my own affairs
Call me another way.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: aside. What affairs; what affairs; demand that, Dolthead! the Rogue will lose a quarrell for want of wit to ask that question.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: May I enquire where your affairs conduct you?

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.l: aside. Well sayd again; I beg thy pardon.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Oh, it concerns you not.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Perhaps it does.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: You are too inquisitive: nor am I bound
To satisfy and Enemies request.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: You have a Ring upon your finger Diomede,
And given you by a Lady,

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: If it were; 'Twas given to one who can defend her gift.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: aside. So, so; the boars begin to gruntle at one another: set up your bristles now a'both sides: whet and foam Rogues.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: You must restore it Greek, by Heaven you must:
No spoil of mine shall grace a Traitors hand.
And, with it, give me back the broken vows
Of my false fair; which, perjur'd as she is,
I never will resigne, but with my Soul.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Then thou it seems art that for saken fool
Who wanting merit to preserve her heart,
Repines in vain to see it better plac'd;
But know, (for now I take a pride to grieve thee)
Thou art so lost a thing in her esteem
I never heard thee nam'd; but some scorn follow'd:
Thou wert our table take for laughing meals:
Thy name our sportful theme for Evening walks:
And intermissive hours of cooler Love:
When hand in hand we went. [Troil.] Hell and furies!

sp.speaker: Thersi.
sp.l: Aside. O well stung Scorpion!
sp.p: Now Menclaus his Greek horns are out o' doors, there's a new Cuckold start up on the Trojan side.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Yet this was she, ye Gods that very she,
Who in my arms lay melting all the Night;
Who kiss'd and sigh'd, and sigh'd, and kiss'd again,
As if her Soul flew upward to her lips,
To meet mine there, and panted at the passage.
Who loath to finde the breaking day, look'd out,
And shrunk into my bosome, there to make
A little longer darkness.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Plagues and tortures!

sp.speaker: Thersi.
sp.p: Good, good, by Pluto! their fool's mad to lose his harlot; and our fools mad, that tother fool had her first: if I sought peace now, I cou'd tell 'em there's punk enough to satisfie 'em both: whore sufficient! but let 'em worry one another, the foolish currs; they think they can never have enough of carrion.

sp.speaker: Aeneas.
sp.l: My Lords, this sury is not proper here,
In time of truce; if either side be injur'd
To morrow's Sun will rise apace, and then—

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: And then! but why should I defer till then?
My blood calls now, there is no truce for Traytors.
My vengeance rowls within my breast, it must
It will have vent.—

sp.speaker: Diom
sp.l: Hinder us not Aeneas,
My blood rides high as his, I trust thy honour;
And know thou art too brave a foe to break it.—

sp.speaker: Thersi.
sp.p: Now Moon! now snine sweet Moon! let 'em have just light enough to make their passes: and not light enough to ward 'em

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Drawing too. By Heav'n he comes on this who strikes the first,
You both are mad, is this like gallant men
To fight at midnight; at the Murderers hour?
When only guilt and rapine draws a Sword?
Let night enjoy her dues of soft repose;
But let the Sun behold the brave mans courage.
And this I dare engage for Diomede
Foe though I am, he shall not hide his head,
But meet you in the very face of danger.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: putting up. Be't so: and were it on some precipice
High as Olympus, and a Sea beneath
Call when thou dar'st, just on the sharpest point
I'le meet, and tumble with thee to destruction.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: A gnawing conscience haunts not guilty men
As I'le haunt thee, to summon thee to this,
Nay, should'st thou take the Stygian lake for refuge
I'le plunge in after, through the boiling flames
To push thee hissing down the vast Abysse.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Where shall we meet?

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Before the Tent of Calchas:
Thither, through all your Troops, Ile fight my way;
And in the sight of perjur'd Cressida
Give death to her through thee.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Tis largely promis'd.
But I disdain to answer with a boast;
Be sure thou shalt be met.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: And thou be found.

div.stage: [Exeunt Troilus Aeneas, one way: Diomede the other.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: Now the furies take Aeneas, for letting 'em sleep upon their quarrell: who knows but rest may cool their brains, and make 'em rise maukish to mischief upon consideration? May each of 'em dream he sees his Cockatrice in to ' ther's arms: and be stabbing one another in their sleep, to remember 'em of their business when they wake: let 'em be punctual to the point of honour; and if it were possible let both be first at the place of Execution. Let neither of 'em have cogitation enough, to consider 'tis a whore they fight for: and let 'em vallue their lives at as little as they are worth. And lastly let no succeeding fools take warning by 'em; but in imitation of them when a Strumpet is in question,
sp.l: Let 'em beneath thair feet all reason trample;
And think it great to perish by Example.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: THe blew mists rise from off the nether grounds,
And the Sun mounts apace: to arms, to arms;
I am resolv'd to put to th' utmost proof
The fate of Troy this day.

sp.speaker: Andro.
sp.l: aside. Oh, wretched woman, oh!

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Methought heard you sigh, Andromache!

sp.speaker: Andro.
sp.l: Did you my Lord?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Did you my Lord? You answer indirectly,
Just when I sayd that I wou'd put our fate
Upon th' extreamest proof, you fetch'd a groan;
And, as you check'd your self, for what you did
You stifl'd it, and stopt. Come you are sad.

sp.speaker: Andro.
sp.l: The Gods forbid.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: What should the Gods forbid?

sp.speaker: Andro.
sp.l: That I shou'd give you cause of just offence.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: You say well: but you look not cheerfully.
I mean this day to waste the stock of war,
And lay it prodigally out in blows:
Come gird my sword, and smile upon me, love;
Like victory come flying to my arms;
And give me earnest of desir'd successe.

sp.speaker: Andro.
sp.l: The Gods protect you; and restore you to me.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: What, grown a Coward! thou wert us'd Andromache,
To give my courage, courage: thou woudst cry
Go Hector; day grow's old; and part of Fame
Is ravish'd from thee, by thy sloathfull stay.

sp.speaker: Andro.
sp.l: aside. What shall I do, to seem the same I was!
Come let me gird thy fortune to thy side:
And conquest sit as close, and sure as this.
sp.stage: [She goes to gird his Sword; and it falls.]
sp.l: Now mercy, Heaven! the Gods avert this omen!

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: A foolish omen! take it up again;
And mend thy errour.

sp.speaker: Andro.
sp.l: I cannot: for my hand obeys me not.
But as in slumbers, when we fain wou'd run
From our imagin'd fears, our idle feet
Grow to the ground, our struggling voice dyes inward,
So now, when wou'd force my self to chear you
My faltring tongue can give no glad presage;
Alas, I am no more Andromache.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Why then thy former Soul is flown to me:
For I, me thinks, am lifted into ayr:
As if my mind, mastring my mortal part
Wou'd bear my exalted body to the Gods.
Last night I dreamt Jove sate on Ida's top
And beckning with his hand divine from far,
He pointed to a quire of Demi-gods,
Bacchus, and Hercules, and all the rest
Who free from humane toils had gain'd the pitch
Of blest eternity: lo there he sayd;
Lo there's a place for Hector.

sp.speaker: Andro.
sp.l: Be to thy Enemies this boding dream!

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Why it portends me honour and renoun.

sp.speaker: Andro.
sp.l: Such honour, as the Brave gain after death.
For I have dreamt all night of horrid slaughters,
Of trampling horses, and of Charriot wheels
Wading in blood up to their Axeltrees.
Of fiery Demons gliding down the Skyes,
And Ilium brighten'd with a midnight blaze;
O therefore, if thou lov'st me, go not forth.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Go to thy bed again; and there dream better.
Ho bid my Trumpet Sound.

sp.speaker: Andro.
sp.l: No notes of sally for the Heaven's sweet sake.
Tis not for nothing when my Spirits droop:
This is a day when thy ill Starrs are strong
When they have driv'n thy helpless genius down
The steep of Heaven to some obscure retreat.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: No more; ev'n as thou lov st my fame no more:
My honour stands ingag'd to meet Achilles:
What will the Grecians think; or what will he,
Or what will Troy; or what wilt thou thy self
When once this ague fit of fear is ore;
If I should lose my honour for a dream.

sp.speaker: Andro.
sp.l: Your Enemies too well your courage know,
And Heaven abhorrs the forfiet of rash vows
Like spotted livers in a Sacrifice.
I cannot; O I dare not let you go:
For when you leave me, my presaging minde
Says, I shall never, never see you more.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Thou excellently good, but oh too soft,
Let me not scape the danger of this day,
But I have struggling in my manly Soul
To see those modest tears, asham'd to fall,
And witness any part of woman in thee!
And now I fear, lest thou should'st think it fear,
If thus disswaded, I refuse to fight,
And stay inglorious in thy arms at home.

sp.speaker: Andro.
sp.l: Oh cou'd I have that thought I shou'd not love thee;
Thy soul is proof to all things but to kindness.
And therefore t'was that I forebore to tell thee
How mad Cassandra, full of prophecy
Ran round the streets, and like a Bacchanal
Cry'd hold him Priam, 'tis an ominous day,
Let him not go; for Hector is no more.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Our life is short but to extend that span
To vast Eternity is virtues work.
Therefore to thee, aad not to fear of fate
Which once must come to all, give I this day
But see thou move no more the like request:
For rest assur'd that to regain this hour
To morrow will I tempt a double danger:
Mean time, let Destiny attend thy leisure.
I reckon this one day a blank of of life.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Where are you Brother? now in honour's name,
What do you mean to be thus long nnarm'd?
Th' imbattel'd Souldiers throug about the gates:
The Matrous to the turrets tops ascend
Holding their helplesse children in their arms,
To make you early known to their young eyes,
And Hector is the universal shout.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Bid all unarm, I will not fight to day.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Employ some coward to bear back this news,
And let the children hoot him for his pains;
By all the gods and by my just revenge,
This sun shall shine the last for them or us:
These noisy streets or yonder ecchoing plains
Shall be to morrow silent as the grave.

sp.speaker: Andro.
sp.l: O Brother do not urge a brother's fate,
But let this rack of heav'n and earth rowl o're,
And when the storm is past put out to sea.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Oh now I know from whence his change proceeds,
Some frantick Augur has observ'd the skyes;
Some victim wants a heart, or crow flys wrong;
By heav'n 'twas never well since sawcy Priests
Grew to be Masters of the listning herd;
And into Miters cleft the Regal Crown.
Then as the Earth were scanty for their pow'r,
They drew the pomp of Heav'n to wait on them;
Shall I go publish Hector dares not sight
Because a mad-man dreamt he talk'd with Jove?
What cou'd the God see in a brain-sick Priest
That he should sooner talk to him then me?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: You know my name's not liable to fear.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Yes, to the worst of fear, to superstition.
But whether that or fondnesse of a wife,
(The more unpardonable ill) has seiz'd you,
Know this, the Grecians think you fear Achilles,
And that Polixena has beg'd your life.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: How! that my life is beg'd, and by my sister?

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Vlysses so inform'd me at our parting,
With a malicious and disdainfull smile:
'Tis true, he said not in broad words you fear'd,
But in well-manner'd terms 'twas so agreed
Achilles shou'd avoid to meet with Hector.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: He thinks my Sisters treason, my petition,
That largely vaunting in my heat of bloud
More then I cou'd, it seems, or durst perform,
I sought evasion.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: And in private pray'd.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: O yes, Polixena, to beg my life.

sp.speaker: Andro.
sp.l: He cannot think so, do not urge him thus.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Not urge me! then thou think'st I need his urging.
By all the Gods shou'd Jove himself descend,
And tell me Hector thou deserv'st not life
But take it as a boon; I wou'd not live.
But that a Mortal man, and he of all men
Shou'd think my life were in his power to give,
I will not rest, till prostrate on the ground
I make him Athiest- like, implore his breath
Of me and not of Heaven.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Then you'I refuse no more to fight.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Refuse! I'le not be hinder'd, Brother.
I'le through and through 'em, ev'n their hindmost ranks.
Till I have found that large siz'd boasting fool
Who dare presume my life is in his gift.

sp.speaker: Andro.
sp.l: Farewell, farewell: 'tis vain to strive with fate:
Cassandra's raging God inspires my breast,
With truths that must be told and not believ'd.
Look how he dyes! look how his eye turns pale!
Look how his blood bursts out at many vents!
Hark how Troy roars, how Hecuba crys out
And widow'd fill all the streets with screams!
Behold distraction, frenzy and amazement,
Like Antiques meet, and tumble upon heaps!
And all cry Hector; Hectors dead! oh Hector!

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: What sport will be when we return at Evening,
To laugh her out of count'nance for her dreams!

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: I have not quench'd my eyes with dewy sleep this Night;
But fiery fumes mount upward to my brains,
And when I breathe, methinks my nostrills hiss!
I shall turn Basilisk! and with my sight
Do my hands work, on Diomede this day.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: To Arms, to Arms, the vantguards are ingag'd:
Let us not leave one Man to guard the Walls,
Both Old and young, the coward and the brave,
Be Summond all, our utmost fate to try;
And as one body move, whose Soul am I.

div.head: SCENE II. The Camp.
div.stage: Alarm within. Enter Agamemnon, Ulysses, Menelaus, Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: THus far the promise of the day is fair:
Aeneas rather loses ground than gains,
I saw him overlabour'd, taking breath;
And leaning on his spear, behold our Trenches
Like a fierce Lyon looking up to toyls,
Which yet he durst not leap.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: And therefore distant death does all the work:
The flights of whistling darts make brown the sky,
Whose clashing points strike fire, and guild the dusk:
Those that reach home, from neither host are vain,
So thick the prease; so lusty are their arms,
That death seem'd never sent with better will!
Nor was with less concernment entertain'd.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Now Nestor, what's the news?

sp.speaker: Nestor.
sp.l: I have descry'd,
A clow'd of dust that mounts in pillars upwards;
Expanding as it travells to our Camp,
And from the midst I heard a bursting showt,
That rent the Heavens! as if all Troy were swarm'd,
And on the wing this way.

sp.speaker: Menel.
sp.l: Let 'em come, let 'em come.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Where's great Achilles!

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: Think not on Achilles:
Till Hector drag him from his Tent to fight,
(Which sure he will, for I have laid the train.)

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: But young Patroclus leads his Myrmydons;
And in their front, ev'n in the face of Hector,
Resolves to dare the Trojans.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Haste Vlysses, bid Ajax issue forth, and second him.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: Oh Noble General, let it not be so.
Oppose not rage, while rage is in its force;
But give it way awhile; and let it waste:
The rising deluge is not stopt with dams,
Those it orebears, and drowns the hopes of harvest.
But wisely manag'd its divided strength
Is sluc'd in channels, and securely drain'd:
First, let small parties dally with their fury.
But when their force is spent and unsupply'd
The residue with mounds may be restrain'd,
And dry-shod, we may pass the naked ford.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: Ho, ho, ho!

sp.speaker: Menel.
sp.p: Why dost thou laugh, unseasonable fool!

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: Why thou fool in season, cannot a man laugh, but thou thinkst he makes horns at thee! Thou Prince of the Herd, what hast thou to do with laughing! Tis the prerogative of man to laugh! Thou Risibility without Reason: thou subject of laughter; Thou fool Royall:

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.p: But tell us the occasion of thy mirth?

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: Now a man asks me, I care not if I answer to my own kinde: why the Enemies are broken into our Trenches: Fools like Menelaus fall by thousands; yet not a humane Soul departs on either side. Troilus and Ajax have almost beaten one anothers heads off; but are both immortal for want of brains. Patroclus has kill'd Sarpedon; and Hector Patroclus: So there's a towardly springing fop gone off: He might have made a Prince one day: But now he's nipt in the very budd and promise of a most prodigious Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Bear off Patroclus body to Achilles:
Revenge will arm him now, and bring us ayd.
Th' alarm Sounds near; an shouts are driv'n upon us,
As of a crowd confus'd in their retreat.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: Open your Ranks, and make these mad men way:
Then close again, to charge upon their backs:
And quite consume the Reliques of the warr.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: What shoales of fools one battle sweeps away!

How it purges families of younger Brothers! Highways of Robbers,
and Cities of Cuckold-makers! There's nothing like a pitch'd Battle, for these brisk Addle-heads! Your Physitian is a pretty fellow; but his fees make him tedious; he rids not fast enough; the fools grow upon him, and their horse bodies are poyson proof. Your pestilence is a quicker Remedy; but it has not the grace to make distinction; it huddles up honest men and Rogues together. But your battle has discretion; it picks out all the forward fools. And sowses 'em together into Immortality. [Shouts and alarm within. Plague upon these drums and trumpets! these sharp sawces of the War, to get fools an Appetite to fighting! what do I 'em? I shall be miscaken for some valiant Asse, and dye a Martyr, in a wrong Religion!

div.stage: Here Grecians fly over the stage, pursued by Trojans: One Trojan turns back upon Thersites who is flying too.

sp.speaker: Trojan.
sp.p: Turn slave and fight.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: turning. What art thou!

sp.speaker: Troj.
sp.p: A Bastard Son of Priam's.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: I am a Bastard too: I love Bastards: I am Bastard in body, Bastard in minde, Bastard in valour; in every thing illegitimate. A Bear will not fasten upon a Bear; why should one Bastard offend another! let us part fair, like true Sons of Whores; and have the fear of our Mothers before our eyes.

sp.speaker: Troj.
sp.p: The Devil take thee Coward.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: Now wou'd I were either invisible, or invulnerable? these Gods have a fine time on't; they can see and make mischief, and never feel it. [Clattring of swords at both doors; he runs each way, and meets the noise. A pox clatter you; I am compass'd in! Now wou'd I were that blockhead Ajax for a minute: some sturdy Trojan will poach me up with a long pole! and then the Rogues may kill one another upon free cost, and have no body lest to laugh at 'em:
sp.l: Now Destruction! now Destruction!

div.stage: Enter Hector and Troilus driving in the Greeks.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: to Ther. Speak what part thou fightst on!

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.l: I fight not at all: I am for neither side.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Thou art a Greek: art thou a match for Hector.
Art thou of blood and honour?

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: No, I am a rescall: a scurvy railing knave; a very filthy Rogue.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: I do believe thee; live.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: God a mercy, that thou wilt believe me: but the Devil break thy neck for frighting me:

sp.speaker: Troilus.
sp.p: returning. What Prisoner have you there?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: A gleaning of the war: a Rogue he says.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.p: Despatch him and away.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: Hold, hold: what is't no more but dispatch a man and away! I am in no such hast: I will not dye for Greece; I hate Greece, and by my good will wou'd nere have been born there; I was mistaken into that Country, and betray'd my parents to be born there. And besides I have a mortal Enemy amongst the Grecians, one Diomede a damned villain, and cannot dye with a safe conscience till I have first murther'd him.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.p: Shew me that Diomede and thou shalt live.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: Come along with me and I'le conduct thee to Calchas his Tent, where I believe he's now making were with the Priests daughter.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Here we must part, our destinies devide us;
Brother and friend, farewell.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: When shall we meet?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: When the Gods please: if not, we once must part.
Look; on you hill their squander'd Troops unite;

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: If I mistake not, 'tis their last Reserve:
The storm's blown ore; and those but after drops.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I wish our Men be not too far ingag'd:
For few we are and spent; as having born
The burden of the Day: but hap what can
They shall be charg'd: Achilles must be there;
And him I seek, or death.
Devide our Troops; and take the fresher half.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: O Brother,

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: No dispute of Ceremony!
These are enow for me; in faith enow:
There bodies shall not flag while I can lead;
Not wearied limbs confess mortality,
Before those Ants that blacken all you hill
Are crept into their Earth: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Farewell; come Greek:

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: Now these Rival-rogues will clapperclaw one another, and I shall have the sport on't.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Which way went Hector?

sp.speaker: Myrmyd.
sp.l: Up you sandy hill:
You may discern 'em by their smoaking track;
A wavering body working with bent hams
Against the rising, spent with painfull march,
And by loose-footing cast on heaps together.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: O thou art gone! thou sweetest, best of friends;
Why did I let thee tempt the shock of war
Ere yet thy tender nerves had strung thy limbs,
And knotted into strength. Yet, though too late,
I will, I will revenge the, my Patroclus!
Nor shall thy Ghost thy Murtherer's long attend,
But thou shalt hear him calling Charon back,
Ere thou art wasted to the farther shore.
Make hast, my Soldiers: give me this days pains.
For my dead friend: strike every hand with mine,
Till Hector breathless, on the ground we lay!
Revenge is honour, the securest way.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.l: That's Calcha's tent.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Then that one spot of Earth contains more falshood
Than all the Sun sees in his race beside.
That I shou'd trust the Daughter of Priest!
Priesthood, that makes a merchandise of Heaven!
Priesthood that sells eve'n to their prayr's and blessings!
And forces us to pay for our own cousnage!

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.l: Nay cheats Heav'n too with entrails and with offals;
Gives it the garbidge of a Sacrifice
And keeps the best of private Luxury.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Thou hast deserv'd thy life, for cursing Priests:
That back, that nose; those eyes are beautiful:
Live thou, art honest; for thou hat'st a Priest.

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: aside. Farewell Trojan; if I scape with life, as I hope; and thou art knock'd o'th head, as I hope too; I shall be the first that ever scap'd the revenge of a Priest, after cursing him; and thou wilt not be the last, I prophecy that a Priest will bring to ruin.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Me thinks my soul is rowz'd to her last work:
Has much to do, and little time to spare.
She starts within me, like a Traveller
Who sluggishly out-slept his morning hour
And mends his pace, to reach his Inn betimes.
A Noise of Arms! the Traitor may be there:
Or else, perhaps, that conscious scene of Love,
The Tent may hold him, yet I dare not search
For Oh I fear to find him in that place.

sp.speaker: Cress
sp.l: Where is he? I'le be justify'd or dye.

sp.speaker: Calch.
sp.l: So quickly vanish'd! he was here but now:
He must be gone to search for Diomede,
For Diomede told me, here they were to fight.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.l: Alas! (Calch.) you must prevent, and not complain.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.l: If Troilus dye, I have no share in life.

sp.speaker: Calch.
sp.l: If Diomede sink beneath the sword of Troilus,
We lose not only a Protector here,
But are debard all future means of flight.

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: What then remains!

sp.speaker: Calch.
sp.l: To interpose betimes
Betwixt their swords; or if that cannot be
To intercede for him, who shall be vanquish'd,
Fate leaves no middle course.—

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: Ah me I hear e'm;
And fear 'tis past prevention.

div.stage: Enter Diomede, retiring before Troilus, and falling as he enters.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Now beg thy life, or dye.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: No: use thy fortune:
I loath the life, which thou canst give, or take.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Scornst thou my mercy villain!— take thy wish.—

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: Hold, hold your hand my Lord, and hear me speak.

div.stage: Troilus turns back: in which time Diomede rises; Trojans and Greeks enter, and rank themselves on both sides of their Captains.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Did I not hear the voice of perjur'd Cressida?
Com'st thou to give the last stab to my heart?
As if the proofs of all thy former falshood
Were not enough convincing, com'st thou now
to beg my Rivals life!
Whom, Oh, if any spark of truth remain'd,
Thou coud'st not thus, ev'n to my face prefer!

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: What shall I say! that you suspect me false
Has struck me dumb! but let him live my Troilus,
By all our loves, by all our past endearments
I do adjure thee spare him.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Hell, and death!

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: If ever I had pow'r to bend your mind,
Believe me still your faithful Cressida:
And though my innocence appear like guilt,
Because I make his forfeit life my suit,
'Tis but for this, that my return to you
Wou'd be cut off for ever by his death.
My father, treated like a slave and scorn'd,
My self in hated bonds a Captive held.

sp.speaker: Troil
sp.l: Cou'd I believe thee, cou'd I think thee true
In triumph wou'd I bear thee back to Troy,
Though Greece could rally all her shatter'd troops,
And stand embatteld to oppose my way.
But, Oh, thou Syren, I will stop my ears
To thy enchanting notes; the winds shall bear
Upon their wings, thy words more light then they.

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: Alass I but dissembled love to him;
If ever he had any proof beyond
What modesty might give.—

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: No! witnesse this—
There, take her Trojan; thou deserv'st her best,
You good, kind-natur'd, well-believing fools
Are treasures to a woman.
I was a jealous, hard vexatious Lover
And doubted ev'n this pledge till full possession:
But she was honourable to her word;
And I have no just reason to complain.

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: O, unexampled, frontlesse impudence!

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Hell show me such another tortur'd wretch, as Troilus!

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Nay, dare grieve not: I resigne her freely up:
I'm satisfi'd: and dare engage for Cressida,
That if you have a promise of her person,
She shall be willing to come out of debt.

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: [kneeling.] My only Lord: by all those holy vows
Which if there be a pow'r above are binding,
Or, if there be a Hell below, are fearful,
May every imprecation, which your rage
Can wish on me, take place, if I am false.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Nay, since you're so concern'd to be believ'd,
I'm sorry I have press'd my charge so far;
Be what you wou'd be thought: I can be grateful.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: Grateful! Oh torment! now hells blewest flames
Receive her quick; with all her crimes upon her.
Let her sink spotted down. Let the dark host
Make room; and point: and hisse her, as she goes.
Let the most branded Ghosts of all her Sex
Rejoyce, and cry, here comes a blacker fiend.
Let her—

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: Enough my Lord; you've said enough:
This faithlesse, perjur'd, hated Cressida,
Shall be no more, the subject of your Curses:
Some few hours hence, and grief had done your work;
But the your eyes had miss'd the satisfaction
Which thus I give you— thus—

div.stage: [She stabs her self they both run to her.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Help; save her, help.

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: Stand off; and touch me not, thou Traitor, Diomede:
But you, my only Troilus come near:
Trust me the wound which I have giv'n this breast
Is far lesse painful, then the wound you gave it.
Oh, can you yet believe, that I am true!

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: This were too much, ev'n if thou hadst been false!
But, Oh, thou purest, whitest innocence,
(For such I know thee now) too late I know it!
May all my curses, and ten thousand more
Heavier than they, fall back upon my head,
Pelion and Ossa from the Gyants graves,
Be torn by some avenging Deity,
And hurld at me, a bolder wretch then they,
Who durst invade the Skys!

sp.speaker: Cressi.
sp.l: Hear him not Heavens!
But hear me bless him with my latest breath:
And since I question not your hard decree,
That doom'd my days unfortunate and few,
Add all to him, you take away from me;
And I dye happy that he thinks me true.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: She's gone for ever, and she blest me dying!
Cou'd she have curs'd me worse! she dy'd for me;
And like a woman, I lament for her:
Distraction pulls me several ways at once,
Here pity calls me to weep out my eyes;
Despair then turns me back upon my self,
And bids me seek no more, but finish here:
Ha, smilst thou Traitor, thou instruct'st me best,
And turn'st my just revenge to punish thee.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Thy worst, for mine has been before hand with thee,
I triumph in thy vain credulity,
Which levels thy despairing state to mine:
But yet thy folly to believe a foe;
Makes thine the sharper, and more shamefull loss.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: By my few moments of remaining life;
I did not hope for any future joy,
But thou hast given me pleasure ere I dye:
To punish such a Villain.— Fight a part.
For Heaven and hell have mark'd him out for me,
And I shou'd grudg ev'n his least drop of blood,
To any other hand.—

div.stage: [Troilus and Diomede fight, and both parties engage at the same time: The Trojans make the Greeks retire, and Troilus makes Diomede give ground and hurts him, Trumpets sound, Achilles Enters with his Myrmidons, on the backs of the Trojans, who fight in a Ring encompass'd round: Troilus singling Diomede gets him down and kills him: and Achilles kills Troilus upon him. All the Trojans dye upon the place, Troilus last.
Enter Agamemnon, Menelaus, Ulisses, Nestor, Ajax, and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: Our toyls are done, and those aspiring Walls
(The work of Gods, and almost mateing Heaven,)
Must crumble into rubbish on the plain.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: When mighty Hector fell beneath thy Sword,
Their Old foundations shook, their nodding Towers
Threatned from high, the amaz'd Inhabitants:
And Guardian Gods for fear forsook their fanes.

sp.speaker: Achill.
sp.l: Patroclus, now be quiet: Hectors dead:
And as a second offring to thy Ghost,
Lyes Troilus high upon a heap of slain:
And noble Diomede beneath; whose death
This hand of mine reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: Reveng'd it basely.
For Troilus fell by multitudes opprest;
And so fell Hector, but 'tis vain to talk.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: Hayl Agamemnon! truly Victor now!
While secret envy, and while open pride,
Among thy factious Nobles discord threw;
While publique good was urg'd for private ends,
And those thought Patriots, who disturb'd it most;
Then like the headstrong horses of the Sun,
That light which shou'd have cheer'd the World, consum'd it:
Now peacefull order has resum'd the reynes,
Old time looks young, and Nature seems renew'd:
Then, since from homebred Factions ruine springs,
Let Subjects learn obedience to their Kings.

div.head: The Epilogue.
div.l: THese cruel Critiques put me into passion;
For in their lowring looks I reade damnation:
Ye expect a Satyr, and I seldom fail,
When I'm first beaten, 'tis my part to rail.
You British fools, of the Old Trojan stock,
That stand so thick one cannot miss the flock,
Poets have cause to dread a keeping Pit,
When Womens Cullyes come to judge of Wit.
As we strow Rats-bane when we vermine fear,
'Twere worth our cost to scatter fool-bane here.
And after all our judging Fops were serv'd,
Dull Poets too shou'd have a dose reserv'd,
Such Reprobates, as past all sence of shaming
Write on, and nere are satisfy'd with damming,
Next, those, to whom the Stage does not belong
Such whose Vocation onely is to Song;
At most to Prologue, when for want of time
Poets take in for Iournywork in Rhime.
But I want curses for those mighty shoales,
Of scribling Chlorisses, and Phillis fools,
Those Ophs shou'd be restraind, during their lives,
From Pen and Ink, as Madmen are from knives:
I cou'd rayl on, but 'twere a task as vain
As preaching truth at Rome, or wit in Spain,
Yet to huff out our Play was worth my trying,
John Lilbourn scap'd his Iudges by defying:
If guilty, yet I'm sure oth' Churches blessing,
By suffering for the Plot, without confessing.
